TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Is the minister aware that 58 per cent of respondents to the New South Wales social services hotline, conducted on 28 October, said that there had been a drop in quality at their local child‐care centre? Does the minister agree that the accreditation system, which was introduced to guarantee quality, is becoming ineffective because of cost‐saving measures brought about by $820 million that have been cut out of child care in the last two years by this government?

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. I see that senators opposite have what appears to be advertising material in the chamber. I do not think that is appropriate to have in the chamber, nor do I think it is appropriate for one of the senator's staff to hand out material of that nature in the chamber.
—That is correct. I am sending a note to those concerned, Senator.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Neal for the question. I have been around long enough in this game to question any survey—any phone polling—that is done. The survey that Senator Neal refers to is one organised by the New South Wales government. That is the first point.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point is that it was a half‐day phone‐in, asking anybody that had got a problem `to ring on in and let us know what your beef is'—a great survey, very dispassionate and aimed at getting the truth! Four hundred people rang in to the survey. I worked out that, as there are 395,000 people that access child care in Australia, and get the rebate, that is 0.001 per cent of the sample.
Senator O'Brien interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —So 0.001 per cent of the sample rang in, Senator O'Brien. They rang in to voice their complaints. Four hundred people rang in to the survey. So here we go again with another scaremongering attitude towards this. The approach was obviously fundamentally flawed. Any hotline set up for `parents with problems' to `ring in and talk to us' of course is going to attract callers who have got particular concerns. We did not hear, for example, from the large proportion of families who remain satisfied with their child‐care arrangements and understand the need to target scarce resources to those most in need.

BREAK.PARA: Fee increases claimed by the New South Wales Council of Social Service of between $15 and $40 per week per child are grossly overstated. National data indicates that community sector fee increases average around $14 per week compared with a one dollar per week increase for the 70 per cent of families using the private centres.

In relation to the quality of care, which was the second part of Senator Neal's question, the regulatory framework of state and territory children's services regulations are a state and territory responsibility. If 400 people rang in complaining about the New South Wales government, good on them, because the New South Wales government is responsible for the regulation of that quality care. I applaud them for ringing in to their own government to let it know that they were getting such poor quality care from their own state regulatory authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are flick‐passing this. You can't answer the question. You are flick‐passing.
—You don't like to hear it, Senator Forshaw, but it is the truth: 0.001 per cent ring in to the New South Wales government and tell them that is the problem.

BREAK.PARA: The Commonwealth quality improvement and accreditation system for long day care centres is in place and a review is to be undertaken as a priority by the new Child Care Advisory Council, and that will be announced shortly. The system is designed to build on the minimum standards prescribed and monitored by state and territory regula tions. I repeat again: they are state and territory regulations.

It needs, of course, the informed involvement of parents, and one would expect that that should be so and that is to be applauded. Commonwealth initiatives, such as the child‐care access hotline and the quality improvement and accreditation system, are helping to raise parents' awareness of good quality child care so that they can make more informed choices. Centres are also encouraged to work in partnership with parents. That is what our policy is about—choices, choice by the parents, unlike the previous government's where that was not available.

The Commonwealth provides approximately $20 million for support, training and advice to children's services to assist in achieving quality outcomes for children and, after all, that is what we should all be supporting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Despite your views, Minister, there is a great deal of concern in the community about what is happening with child care. Are the budget cuts to child care made by this government determined by budgetary constraints or are they determined by the view of the Lyons Forum of what the role of women should be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The dear old Lyons Forum is accorded much more strength and power than actually exists within it. I am a proud member of the Lyons Forum and I wish we could influence the budget, as Senator Neal suggests. The Lyons Forum is concerned about families. It is concerned about mothers, fathers and children—and long may it be so that it is concerned, because that is what this government is concerned about: the quality of child care and that child care should be available to working mothers so that it improves the quality of their home life and the quality of both parents' lives. So we get the dear old Lyons Forum dragged into it again. As I say, it would be wonderful if it had such influence but, regrettably, it does not.

ANSWER.PARA: An allegation is made that we have made cuts in child care. In fact, child care under our policy is designed to improve choices for parents, both fathers and mothers, increasing expenditure and giving greater choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Increased expenditure every year.
—Thank you to Senator Newman who has a keen interest in this matter. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Minister, the Howard government has delivered record low inflation, record low interest rates, record housing affordability, rising retail sales and strong business investment. Will you outline further good news as a result of responsible economic management, and is the government likely to adopt recent alternative proposals to manage the Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the honourable senator on the question, because it is true that the Howard government, through responsible economic management—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Conroy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Conroy, cease interjecting.
—has delivered the lowest inflation rate in 35 years; the lowest interest rates in 20 years, with five reductions in official interest rates since we came to government—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators on my left will cease interjecting.

—the highest rate of home affordability, with housing 25 per cent more affordable than when Labor was in government; and repayment of Labor's massive debt, with a projected budget surplus in 1998‐99. Retail sales are booming, business investment is strong, consumer confidence is up and unemployment is reducing. This is what the Howard government has delivered in just 20 months, through sensible, sound economic management.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to inform the Senate of further good news. I am sure all senators will be pleased that we have now had a 55 per cent decrease in industrial disputes over the year to August, a 2.5 per cent rise in DEETYA's skilled vacancy survey in November—which is a 15 per cent rise since June—and a 9.1 per cent increase in company profits for the year to September.

Thanks to the responsible economic management of the Howard government we are in good shape to withstand the turbulence within the region. As the Reserve Bank Governor said recently, we are in a much better position to handle the financial instability in Asia than we have been at any stage in the last quarter of a century. For that, the Australian people can be grateful to the Howard government.

What would have been the alternative? What is the comparison? Have Labor learnt from their mistakes of the past, which led to the huge budget deficit of $10 billion inherited by this government? Unfortunately, it seems not. Mr Evans, former Senator Evans, the shadow Treasurer, said the other day, `There are all sorts of elements of continuity between the kind of government we were for the last 13 years and the kind of government we would be for the future.'

`How,' he was asked, `are you going to meet these big spending commitments?' He said, `Overwhelmingly, we are relying on growth momentum to generate the additional revenue.' Just the way of the past. No consideration of expenditure restraint. You rely on growth.

Remember what former Treasurer Dawkins said on 9 March 1993. He said, `We have a deficit reduction plan. As the economy grows, the budget will repair itself.' Mr Keating, the then Prime Minister, had the same line. He said, `In time, the deficit just fixes itself. As the economy picks up, the revenue picks up and the deficit falls.'

This opposition—this Labor Party—has not learnt from the mistakes of the past. Mr Evans is saying it again and again. He conceded, `Over the course of the election cycle, of course we may need to have deficit years.' The same story: do not worry about expenditure, just keep pump‐priming the budget, and somehow or other it solves itself.

Australians now know that does not work. This Labor government left Australia precariously poised at the time of the last election, with a $10 billion deficit. One can only wonder what would have been the consequences had a prudent, sensible Howard government not taken the economic decisions that it did to rein in expenditure. They were difficult decisions. They were politically difficult decisions. But they were decisions which were in the best interests of the nation and which can enable us to withstand the turbulence occurring elsewhere within this region. For that all Australians should be pleased. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question. Minister, in view of the financial and currency crisis to our north in Asia, do you have any further comments to make on the alternative proposals put forward for managing the Australian economy?

—As I was saying, nothing has been learnt from the mistakes of the past, so what could we imagine if Labor were returned to government? I guess the record of the past: one million unemployed, the worst recession since the Great Depression, a foreign debt of $185 billion, interest rates at 17 per cent again and a $10 billion budget black hole, as I have said. That was the legacy of Labor. That was their record. They have learnt nothing from the mistakes of the past. They are advocating the same policy course they implemented before. The consequences would be the same economic disaster. Australians deserve better. They now have a government with sound economic management which is providing long‐term benefits for all Australians.

—My question is to Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Was it the intention of the government to force women to reduce their working hours or to leave the work force entirely when it cut $820 million from the child‐care budget or did the government simply not understand the effect an increase in child‐care costs of between $15 and $40 a week would have on an average family's budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Neal keeps putting up these Aunt Sallys and now I have to knock them down because, in fact, there has been an increase in spending on child care. Senator Schacht, you might be interested to know that an estimated $4.9 billion has been allocated to child care over the next four years. It is up from $1.1 billion in 1996‐97 to $1.3 billion in 2000‐01. So tell me about these cuts. Where are they?
—They are making them up.

—You are making them up. Thank you, Senator Parer. I am sure that Councillor June O'Connell, who is the leader of the Liberal Party in the Queensland City Council, is interested in this. Councillor O'Connell is very interested in child care because it affects the Brisbane City Council as well.

ANSWER.PARA: It is obvious that Senator Neal has not cottoned on to the fact that there is more money being spent. Prior to the 1996 budget, real growth in the programs outlays was projected at nine per cent per annum and it is now projected at three per cent per annum. So the actual amount of money is being increased.

Senator Neal also asked me: what is the government doing about this? As I said to Senator Neal previously, it is about greater choice and it is about improved targeting of assistance to families most in need of assistance. We are introducing a system of safety nets for families requiring additional support, such as those with children at risk of abuse or neglect, families with a child with a disability and families in rural and remote areas. We are also introducing a planning system to ensure that families have improved access to care and that government subsidies are sustainable and targeted to areas of highest need. Also, we have introduced a commitment to build on the system of quality improvement by extending it to other sectors.

The final point that Senator Neal made was an allegation that there was a change in female participation in the labour force; that we were forcing people out of the labour force. What are the facts? Firstly, I want to make the point that decisions to increase fees are made by service providers, not by the government. Fee structures in child care are influenced by several factors, such as movements in award wages, charging practices, changes to regulations or increases in overheads such as rates, insurance, utilities, et cetera. The Labor Party would not understand that because none of them have been in private enterprise—not one. So they would not understand about rates, insurance and utilities. Secondly, the Bureau of Statistics labour force figures show that the total participation rate of females with dependent children under 15 years of age has remained relatively stable at around 59 per cent since January 1996. Thirdly, preliminary 1997 child‐care census data show that the average weekly full‐time fee for children attending long day care centres is now around $160. This is only slightly above the trend over the last six years. Increases around that variety have all been between $6 and $10 per year for families using full‐time care.

Claims that the government's child care measures have forced women out of the work force have no basis in fact when a reasonable analysis of the data is undertaken. The government is concerned that fees continue to rise, as they have done since 1991. The new child care council will examine charging practices as a key priority over the next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In fact, Minister, your budget cuts to child care mean less choices for families. Do you believe that it is fair to limit the choices of women by increasing child‐care costs, which reduces their flexibility in hours, reduces their ability to study and, accordingly, restricts their career development and later promotion? Do you think that is fair, Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not think that is fair but, at the same time, I think it would be fairer if Senator Neal stuck to the truth and the facts, instead of closing her ears and closing her eyes to the fact that there are no cuts. The amount of money is increasing. We are giving greater choice to women. We are giving them the opportunity to decide what they should do with their time, as they are rightly entitled to do. Senator Neal, by coming in here with a scaremongering campaign, as you are doing by not sticking to the truth and by relating figures that are not factual, you achieve nothing. It is a reflection on your own inability to understand the facts. I think it reflects more on Senator Neal than it does on the government itself. The government is giving more choice to women because it gives them the opportunity for more choice and more money. It is extending the ability of women to make their own decisions, as they quite rightly should.

—My question is to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. I refer the minister to the new satellite broadcasting services for remote area satellite services. Minister, could you advise the Senate of the expanded services of SBS and Triple J as a result of digital conversion? Will viewers be able to obtain new and existing remote area broadcasting services through a single receiver set? Could you please explain to the Senate what the government is doing to assist 12,000 remote area households and 400 remote Aboriginal self‐help communities convert reception equipment from analog to digital?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very pleasant task to be able to announce that we are doing what Labor promised to do for years but, once again, never delivered on—to extend SBS into the regional areas of Western Australia. That is something that many people in those areas have been waiting very many years to receive. Those living in remote areas generally will receive a comprehensive suite of satellite broadcasting services, including SBS, Triple J and the Parliamentary News Network. In addition, they will be subsidised for the cost of upgrading their equipment to digital.

BREAK.PARA: The new range of services will be provided in conjunction with a digitising of satellite operations, which will also provide for Internet access and potentially allow access to an increasing range of new types of communication services in remote areas, including pay television. The dedicated SBS television service available in remote Western Australia via satellite will be available right across the board for the first time. Again, it will involve subsidised services to 3,500 direct to home satellite households and 120 remote Aboriginal and self‐help communities, in plenty of time for the 1998 World Cup. In total there will be $11.2 million of Commonwealth funding available to provide subsidies for the cost of upgrading. That will directly assist 12,000 direct to home remote households and there will be subsidies towards the replacement of each existing decoder in remote Aboriginal and self‐help communities.

This is tremendously good news for people outside the capital cities, and particularly in Western Australia. Senator Crane, in particular, would appreciate this because, for the first time, these people will be able to get up‐to‐date information on what is really happening in this place. They will not have to rely on all the snide scare campaigns and innuendo that might be peddled when they occasionally get a visit from a Labor senator up to the far north. They will be able to see it for themselves. They will be able to tune in to the ALP conference in Hobart and discover the sheer horror of it all—the fact that nothing has changed. And, just in case some people pretend that it has changed, they will be reminded that former Senator Evans said only last week:
We would be utterly implausible if we tried to present ourselves as a different kind of outfit.

So there it is: a plea of guilty from the highest level. These people will also be able to get access to Senator Schacht's website. They will be able to find out what the disgruntled unionist faction is up to, whether Senator Schacht is actually going to be allowed to go to Hobart and whether he will deliver on the goods that he promised last week after Robert Ray had spent weeks saying that there was a huge difference between platform and policy, and that majority was fair enough. Senator Schacht ate humble pie last week and told us that they were not going to allow any single further sell down from 65 per cent.

All these viewers in remote Western Australia and around the remote communities will be able to tune in and watch it ball by ball as Senator Schacht gets up there, does what the ACTU wants, tells Senator Ray to get lost, and delivers the goods. He is delivering the goods to us, I might say, because he is locking the Australian public out of any further access to a sell down in Telstra and denying the government the opportunity to use additional revenue to repay debt. In other words, he is locked into the tired, old, failed policies of the past which, as Senator Hill quite rightly demonstrated, delivered record unemployment and record high interest rates—all the records you would not want to tell your kids about but which will be available in technicolour sound to all those people in remote areas for the first time. They will be delighted to hear it because they will know that once again Labor failed them. Labor could not get the service there—maybe because it did not want the people to know what Labor was really up to. But now, for the first time, they will know and they will understand who delivers the goods for rural Australia. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, yesterday in Vancouver the Prime Minister unilaterally offered to place on the table the ownership of all Australia's banks as a bargaining chip for an international treaty on financial services. Can you confirm the reported comments of the Prime Minister that the nature of the obligation he will sign will mean that any future Australian government with more concern about the impact of foreign control of all our banks who wished to change the policy would face a massive compensation bill? Given the Liberal Party's long-held concern that treaty obligations should not bind Australia without parliamentary scrutiny, can you, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, assure the Senate that the government will first seek to bring such a major change of policy before the parliament by way of appropriate amendments to the Banking Act before trading off the control of our banks in some smoke-filled room in Vancouver?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable senator has misunderstood the Prime Minister's contribution to this important liberalisation reform agenda. What the Prime Minister announced was Australia's new offer to encourage the finalisation of the WTO financial services negotiations by 12 December. The major change is to offer to remove the prohibition on the foreign acquisition of Australia's four major banks. However, foreign acquisitions would remain subject to the national interest test under Australia's foreign investment policy guidelines and the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975.

ANSWER.PARA: The improved offer is part of Australia's strategy to secure a successful conclusion to the WTO financial services negotiations. We wish to secure an agreement that provides market openings, particularly within the Asia-Pacific, for Australia's financial services exports. I would have thought the honourable senator, having an interest in these matters, would recognise the particular windows of opportunity that seem to be presenting themselves within the region at this time. The Prime Minister specifically is seeking an agreement that protects existing foreign investment, leads to the issuing of new banking and insurance licences and allows for majority control and raised equity participation levels.

Australia's financial services sector is strongly placed to capture new market opportunities created by the WTO negotiations if the considerable barriers to financial services exports and investment were lowered or indeed removed. Australia's significantly improved offer is conditional. It depends upon our trading partners, including developed and developing APEC members, also committing to significant undertakings in the remaining phases of the negotiations.

Rather than take the somewhat negative, pessimistic approach of Senator Murray, the Prime Minister is giving our business, our banks, an opportunity to expand within the region in order that they might grow and prosper and therefore provide benefits for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, thank you for your answer, but my question was whether the parliament would be consulted by way of appropriate amendments to the Banking Act. If you and your government are confident that this move is in the national interest, then bring it to us—bring it to the parliament. Will your government act unilaterally on this matter or will you consult the people through the parliament?

—As I have said, the existing protections through the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 remain. I am not sure whether it is the Prime Minister's intention to seek some further parliamentary sanction in the event that our offer is taken up and embraced by others, but I will seek advice from the Prime Minister on that and let the honourable senator know.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Health Services: Regional and Rural Areas

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. I refer to Dr Wooldridge's speech to the Rural Health Forum in Adelaide, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Underpinning the encouragement the government is giving to public health in rural and remote areas is the clear recognition that Australia has too few medically trained personnel in rural and remote areas.

How does the minister reconcile this with the front‐page story in the Launceston Examiner this morning that there is a health crisis and that Tasmania urgently needs at least another 25 doctors in regional and rural Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Harradine for the question because it highlights a very real problem affecting rural, regional and remote areas of Australia. It was a legacy that we were left with after 13 years of Labor Party neglect. They had a chance to do something about it and they did nothing. They thought the solution was to flood the country with doctors. They did that in an attempt to break the profession. What did it do? It produced many extra doctors in this country. We have this extraordinary paradox, as Senator Harradine highlights, where we have an oversupply of 4,000 general practitioners nationally but a desperate shortage in country Australia, as it struggles to recruit and keep doctors. The oversupply has not led to an increase in the number of doctors in rural areas.

ANSWER.PARA: Tasmania shares the problem, as does the rest of the country: there are too many GPs in the capital but not enough in rural and regional areas. In fact, Launceston has one of the biggest shortfalls in the country, as was mentioned in the paper today. Figures from the Australian Work Force Advisory Committee in 1994 show that many more doctors are needed in Launceston, but in other areas as well.

The government has taken this issue head on since we came into government. We have made significant commitments in the last two budgets to address the quality of general practice services and the medical work force crisis. We have committed over $150 million in new funding for rural health initiatives. Unlike the previous government, we actually went to the rural doctors and asked them what they needed and what we could do to encourage people to stay in rural and remote areas, because it is not just a case of money.

We are making sure that the right of the community to have access to medical care is not subsumed by the desire of doctors to work only in metropolitan areas. We cannot blame them for that—80 per cent of the population of Australia like living on the coastal strip, and we cannot deny the rights of doctors to have the same desire. But, by restricting access to Medicare to those doctors with specialist or general practice postgraduate training or those on a training program, the best opportunities to the remaining graduates are the jobs available in the country. That is the first point.

The second point is that these jobs will be facilitated through the career pathways in rural hospitals, rural clinical assistantships and rural locum positions. The reality is that it is very demanding work. You are expected to be a jack‐of‐all‐trades and competent, and then there is the chance of being sued for any mishap that occurs on the same basis as if you were practising in the city with access to specialised care. It is a very important part of medical practice. The rural doctors need the training but they also need the support and the opportunity to undergo postgraduate training and therefore the opportunity to obtain locums so that they can come down from those rural areas to the regional areas to get further training to bring them up to the latest standards. They recognise that too.

In addition, the government is committed to improving rural specialist services, including obstetrics. You would be well aware, Madam President, of the litigation that occurs in relation to obstetrics, yet we expect that a general practitioner in a rural or remote area is up with the latest technology, has the latest knowledge and the latest facilities and that, if a mishap occurs, they can cope with it. To that end, we have introduced a number of programs to increase the supply of specialist services in rural areas, including a number which focus specifically on obstetric services in rural areas. They include projects funded under the additional specialist training post initiative in rural areas and the rural health support, education and training program.
There are also many personal reasons why doctors come to the city. I understand that more than 60 per cent of doctors in Tasmania are female graduates. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy. My question relates to the development of the oil and gas reserves Australia shares with Indonesia in the Timor Sea. Has Australia benefited from recent discussions with Indonesia about these reserves?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Eggleston for that question. Two weeks ago I met with my counterpart, General Sudjana, in Cairns for the eighth ministerial council meeting under the Timor Gap Zone of Cooperation Treaty. This treaty was ratified to establish a joint authority to govern the development of oil and gas reserves that Australia shares with Indonesia.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators will probably remember that the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, former Senator Gareth Evans, signed that treaty. But he did not do it in the normal way. He did it with a great flamboyant flourish that was quite typical of former Senator Evans. Of course, in the course of events he left a lot of things undone.

The great challenge confronting Minister Sudjana and me was the resolution of the basis for sharing of production benefits of oil and gas deposits in the zone of cooperation. Former Senator Evans just did not address what would occur if processing occurred outside the zone of cooperation, whether it be in Indonesian waters or in Australian waters.

I could not help but notice in the Australian Financial Review of 15 October that Trevor Sykes drew attention to this matter and said it would have to be addressed by me and General Sudjana. He said that we would attempt to sort out the problem. He said, `This is a case of better late than never, because these problems started to emerge years ago and should have been determined then.' So what did the former government do? Yet again it buried its head in the sand and left the problem to the Howard government to fix.

I am pleased to inform the Senate that Minister Sudjana and I struck an agreement on mutually acceptable principles of benefit sharing of the zone of cooperation between the two countries. These are issues which will need to be clarified and this will be achieved on the following agreed principles: firstly, the exploitation of the petroleum resources should proceed without delay; secondly, governments will work towards the objective of equal sharing between the contracting states, Australia and Indonesia, of the benefits of the exploitation of petroleum resources; thirdly, it will achieve optimum commercial utilisation of the exploitation of the petroleum resources, including the location and technology of any processing facilities; and, fourthly, governments will have regard to the development potential and the strengthening of a wider spectrum of future cooperation between the states.

These basic principles of fiscal benefit sharing will pave the way to the development of Bayu‐Undan. The Bayu‐Undan gas discovery is the largest potential development of the zone of cooperation, to date involving some anticipated $10 billion in expenditure. The field extends across two production sharing contracts. The development of this resource could involve the construction of an LNG processing plant at Darwin or Indonesia, or at an offshore location at sea. The environmental impacts of options for development are currently under review. The benefits of the development of similar such resources are huge, with flow-on work to small business and significant employment opportunities.

BREAK.PARA: This resolution is testament to the cooperative and productive spirit of both countries and represents a significant step forward for the region's petroleum industry. Once again the coalition government is removing impediments and facilitating major projects which will deliver real jobs to Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. What are the impediments which remain to the development of this exciting area?

—I said earlier that the Indonesian government and the Howard coalition government are working cooperatively and speedily towards resolving jurisdictional issues. Bayu‐Undan is precisely the type of project put at risk by the inane and short-sighted greenhouse policies promoted by the Democrats, the Greens and, I regret to say, the Australian Labor Party. Bayu‐Undan will export gas most probably to Asia, where it will replace more greenhouse intensive fuels. But, in the process of liquefaction, greenhouse emissions do increase. Under the Democrats' Europhile policy or the ALP's Clinton policy the project would not proceed, although the net greenhouse effect is positive for the global environment. Those on the other side do not care about jobs. They do not care about restoring Australia's economy. What they are looking at is short-term political posturing—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) to questions without notice asked by Senator Neal today, relating to child care.

I have to say that it appears that this government is very much in denial on the issue of child care, because certainly, despite the statements made by Senator Herron, there is a great deal of concern and distress amongst Australian families and parents about the difficulties they are experiencing because of this government's cuts in the area of child care.

It is quite peculiar that the minister continues to deny that the range of cuts amounts to $820 million. Quite contrary to that statement, the budgetary papers prepared by this government clearly indicate that there is $820 million less being spent by this government than was forecast by our government. We saw that there was a major priority to be given to child care and that it was a priority that families should be able to feel secure when they put their children into child care, that there should be a high quality of child care and that those families could actually afford their child care.

It is quite peculiar that this government continues to deny any responsibility for the increasing cost of child care when clearly the EPAC report on child care stated that in fact there would be an increase of between $15 and $25 per week if the operational subsidy for community based child care was abolished. Despite having the EPAC report, despite being aware of the consequences of their actions, this government made exactly that decision. They decided to abolish the operational subsidy for community based child‐care centres after having been advised by EPAC that it would cause an increase of between $15 and $25 a week per child.

That is not the only place that they have made cuts. They have frozen the ceiling for child‐care assistance so that parents pay more. They have reduced the child‐care cash rebate so that families pay more. They have also taken away the operational subsidies for before and after school care for children who access those centres, and that will take effect as of 27 April next year. So not only are cuts having effect already but also in the future there will be a greater impact on families. Again, the government is in denial. They believe that it has no effect on families if child care is more expensive and they think that it has no effect on families if they are no longer able to access formal care, which is the high quality that I believe parents are entitled to expect. Every survey that has been done suggests the two things I have stated: that fees are going up and that the quality of child care is going down.

The minister certainly tried to erode those facts by attacking the survey. But that is not the only source of these statements. It is also what was stated by NACBCS—the child-care centres themselves say that this is the case, not only the New South Wales government. Most peculiar of all, the Department of Health and Family Services itself concedes that the cost of child care has gone up and that parents are paying more for child care than they did previously.

It seems really peculiar to me that the families of Australia are smart enough to know that they are losing out in child care but this government does not seem to want to see it. They believe that it is all right if parents cannot access child care. They believe that it is fine if women have to reduce their hours of work because that fits into their view of what child care is about. Child care should be available so that women are able to exercise their proper choice. Not only should it be available, it should be of a high quality. All the surveys that have been reported in the last six months and the evidence of the department itself suggest that child‐care centres are being forced to make savings. The effect of those savings is that child care goes down in its quality. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —You know when the government is on the right track when you see a report of a peak industry body coming out and supporting reforms to child care. I refer to a report in the Courier‐Mail of 22 November 1997 which reports national child‐care association president, Mr Chris Buck, saying that the legislation was now acceptable to the child‐care industry. It is difficult to see what is being complained about. It is said that there are cuts in child‐care places yet it is as clear as crystal that, in fact, there are additional child‐care places—83,000 extra child‐care places will now be provided over the next four years with 44,000 new private sector places and 39,000 new community long day care, family day care and outside school hours care places between 1997‐98 and 2000‐01. If that does not underscore the government's commitment to and recognition of access to child care as an essential component of women's involvement in the paid work force it is difficult to see what else does.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not only, of course, women's involvement in the work force, it is parents' involvement in the work force. This government is committed to ensuring that all parents have fair and equitable access to both flexible and affordable high quality care options.

A lot of complaints are about the fact that community centres have been rationalised or closed since August 1996. However, they have closed as a result of low utilisation not because of a loss of operational subsidy. Most of the closures have been due to the fact there were not enough child‐care places in areas where they were needed and too many in areas where they were not needed. Just a casual glance at some key statistics that were provided recently to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee shows very starkly that private centres not in receipt of an operational subsidy have been providing far more child‐care places more economically than those centres that received operational subsidies. If you look at the Australia‐wide figures, for instance, you will find that the number of babies aged under two years in child‐care centres Australia‐wide was 14,000 in community based centres receiving a large taxpayer subsidy and 26,000 in private centres not in receipt of an operational subsidy.

When we came to government the child‐care program was out of control, with oversupply in some areas while families elsewhere had little access to the child care they desperately needed. We have set about correcting this problem with our planned approach to both growth and need. Most of the families using centres that have closed have found alternative child care in other centres or in family day care. We have ensured that available funds target those most in need—specifically low and middle income working families. What could be fairer than that? What could be fairer than a child‐care system designed to assist those most in need to work and carry out their family commitments?

The government has made a lot of other changes to child care aimed at correcting problems of access which have been caused by rapid and unregulated growth in child care. The national planning system to influence new long day care centres to locate in areas of most unmet need is an absolute key priority with this government. There are 25,000 extra family day care places to be provided over the next four years and they are intended to lessen the pressure on families in rural and remote areas by providing places where they are most needed. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coonan says that you can tell that the government is on the right track because a private operator in Queensland, who has fought and complained bitterly about every change government has introduced, is finally satisfied with some of the changes. Well, I can tell you when the government is on the right track, Senator—when today's poll tells you that you are ahead of the opposition, not behind it.

SPEECH.PARA: The government is not on the right track. It is sadly off track and today's polls prove it. They prove it conclusively and, what is more, a lot of the people who are voting against this Howard government are women. One of the reasons they are voting against this government is because of the changes to child care. You are creating in child care what you have already done to aged care: a monumental stuff‐up. The people out there know it, and they are already registering their great dissatisfaction about it.

Senator Coonan did the slickest snow job on child care data that I have heard in a long time. To give just one small example of her skating over the facts, she said there were 14,000 baby places in community based child care compared to 26,000 baby places—which, I note she changed to nought‐ to two‐year‐old places—in the private centres. It is just as well she did, because that approximates truth.

There are very, very few baby places in private centres. There are a whole lot of places for six months to 18 months, and certainly above 12 months. There are very few baby places—which most of us take to mean below six months, and certainly below 12 months. The community based centre has borne the weight of baby places, and the community based places are being closed out of existence by this government's direct policies. How can you say community child care is doing all right when 25 community based centres have already closed and many more are under way to closure?

Senator Coonan says the good thing about this government is that it is doing its child‐care planning, but the only long day care centres that were planned for areas of high need were the community based centres, precisely the ones that are now being closed because of this government's direct policy cuts in operational subsidy, in child‐care assistance, in the amount of child‐care cash rebate—direct policies that have seen the closure of the centres that were put where the need was highest and where the community wanted the centres. But let us not view Mr Chris Buck's praise as anything more than it is: the voice of self‐interest.

We have got families and mothers telling us, in report after report, that they are leaving child care because the costs are rising too steeply for them. You talk about choice, but you are restricting the choice of families in child care. They cannot make the same choice for a community based centre now as they used to, because 25, 30 or more are closed or closing. They no longer have access to community based child care. They want the benefits of a child care centre, they want the benefits of a community based centre and they want the benefits of that commitment to quality which has been only very grudgingly given by a large section of the private child care sector—quality that is now under threat from your government's promise to reappraise it. You have not even appointed the national child care advisory committee that will do that.

Child care is in disarray and the families of Australia know it. TALK.START.PARA: —This is just a breathtaking exercise, but then again who would take any notice of Senator Crowley, who comes along to estimates committees as a former minister in this area and actually asks the department what happened when she was minister.
