SPEECH.PARA: These customs tariffs proposals, which we have learnt a lot more about since the government used one of these nifty little devices to scrap the sugar tariff, are quite undemocratic. Government can just table one of these proposals and it is effective from the day it is tabled. It does not matter that the lives of thousands of farmers are going to be affected and that their representatives have no opportunity to vote on what is happening. It does not matter that communities up and down the Queensland coast and in northern New South Wales will be affected by the decision. It does not matter that those who represent them have no opportunity to debate the issue. That does not really matter to this government because it has no commitment to democratic processes. That is becoming clearer and clearer the further it moves into its term—I would suggest probably its first and only term.

The problem is that, once you table one of these proposals and then you try, after the horse has bolted, to do something about it so that people who are affected by the decision have some opportunity to at least have their representatives vote on a small part of it, the government says, `It's gone already.' So, when it comes to the vote, your vote does not really count—and that is fine by the government.

I am glad finally to have the chance to speak in the Senate on this legislation, after a very long campaign in which the Democrats have tried to bring to public notice the inequities of this government's freezing of car and textile tariffs, looking after Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide and then saying, `To heck with Queensland; to heck with northern New South Wales cane farmers. They don't really matter.'

Not only that, but part of the promise—and I am going to repeat the promise that the government made because I want to reinforce what Senator Forshaw said; and I supported every word of his speech—was, `Well, if we take your tariff away, we guarantee to you that we will take other tariffs away, too, so that you won't be affected.' But backbenchers in Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide seem to have more say with this government than backbenchers in Queensland. While preserving tariffs on cars, textiles, clothing and footwear, the sugar tariff was sent down the drain—the $55 per tonne which supported the price received by growers.

Industry and government have consistently said that the tariff had to go or they would not be able to preserve the single desk selling mechanism. That argument is a complete furphy, as Senator Forshaw said, and I want to reinforce what he said. It always has been a furphy. The industry, the government, the Democrats and the cane farmers know that state and federal governments have huge amounts of discretion when it comes to applying competition policy. We have already seen that with the amazing backflips on car and textile tariffs by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). There is no automatic mechanism which determines that restoration of the sugar tariff means that we must lose the single desk selling system.

Let me reinforce that. The Queensland government, which has most say in whether a single desk is retained, is on record as saying that it supports the single desk, and that is in spite of what the Senate might do. I will read to you from a letter from the Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Perrett. It is very up to date; it is dated 21 November 1997. He replies to the member for Mirani as follows:
Dear Mr Malone,
I refer to your inquiries concerning the Government's and my position with regard to the retention of single desk selling of raw sugar.

As you are aware, the Sugar Industry Review Working Party's package of recommendations was endorsed by the Queensland and Commonwealth governments on 16 December 1996 and 4 March 1997 respectively. It recommended the retention of single desk selling of Queensland produced raw sugar by the reconstituted Queensland Sugar Corporation.
Then he goes on to talk about the numbers of the recommendations. He says:
There are no grounds to believe that the Government's or my personal support for the retention of single desk selling has in any way diminished in recent times.
He says that, despite the debate and despite the threat that the sugar tariff could be restored. He continues:
I have consistently made public announcements to the effect that the retention of the system is assured.
I trust that you and your constituents can be assured that there is no policy change or likely to be any attempts to change that policy in this regard.
Yours sincerely
Trevor J Perrett
Minister for Primary Industries
So much for the argument that retaining the sugar tariff threatens the single desk selling. I think that Mr Perrett, in that particular regard, can be trusted.

Another argument used is that, if we restore the tariff, this will affect the merger between CSR Sugar and Mackay Sugar. The Democrats agree that that merger is a good thing. It should go ahead. It is good for the industry. It is certainly good for the sugar refining industry, which is in some trouble. There is no reason why that merger should be threatened by the restoration of a tariff. In fact, it is very interesting that, when the merger proposal was taken to the ACCC to get some assurances from them, they said that they were prepared to let the merger go ahead if the tariff was scrapped because the environment in Australia would be more competitive.

What does that mean? I will tell you what it means. When they talk about the industry being more competitive, that is a code for cheap imports. That is a code for the price of sugar going down. That is code for all the things we have seen happen to other primary industries when successive Australian govern ments have removed tariffs too fast and too early. Look at citrus, pork and tobacco. In an appendix to the committee's report, the ACCC—I hope that sugar farmers take note of this—said:

A number of high capacity refineries have been, or are being constructed, within the Middle East and Asia. The presence of such high capacity refineries creates the potential to displace other sources of refined sugar, thereby forcing existing suppliers to seek out replacement markets. This may result in an increased threat of imports for Australia.

That is not Labor scaremongering; that is not the Democrats scaremongering; that is what the ACCC said in its appendix to the report. I had not seen that appendix until the government included it. Thank you, government, for doing that.

Refined sugar prices in international markets are forecast to remain low due to the increase in world refining capacity, together with an increase in refined sugar availability from the beet growing nations of Europe and from India and Brazil. That is the future for our sugar farmers. But do not take my word for it, and do not even take the word of the ACCC. Take the word of the biggest European sugar producers association—the World Association of Beet and Cane Growers, which was recently interviewed by an Australian journalist and asked what it thought of Australians dumping our sugar tariff this year.

The report says that European growers are shielded by high government protection and dogged by Australian efficiency. What does the Secretary of the World Association of Beet and Cane Growers, Mike Garrod, an English sugarbeet grower, think about Australia scrapping the sugar tariff? Mr Garrod says that Australians are already the cheapest producers of sugar in the world and that it is best placed to compete. He says that we are already world competitive. His son Ian says that if protection of the European beet industry were scrapped, the industry would go under. This English beet farmer says, `If we had to compete at world market prices we'd be wiped out.' I can tell you that the Europeans are going to make sure their sugarbeet farmers survive.

I go back to his father, Mike, who says that if the roles were reversed and the European Union allowed Australian sugar to come in duty free, the European producers would be wiped out. Mr Garrod says that Australian sugar is so cheap the Europeans could not compete. Our farmers are so efficient and, even with the very minimum tariff that they have, are able to threaten the European Union with its high tariffs. Yet we are going to take away from them this very small tariff. I think that Australian cane farmers should do to this government what it deserves. I will wait for the next election because I think that that is when they are going to do it. The Australian government has removed the last little bit of protection of domestic sugar to open the floodgates to cheap imports.

The industry and the government also tell us that farmers support the government. I was told this so many times that I decided to do a survey. The Australian Cane Farmers Association, the voluntary body, provided me with the names and addresses of 5,000 cane farmers. The return on that survey was 15 per cent a couple of weeks ago, and since then I have received many more returns. The result of that survey shows that slightly over 90 per cent of those who responded wanted to keep the tariff. So much for the claim that there was support for the government.
I am pleased that Senator Forshaw read the promises of the Liberal and National Party government of the last election. It is worth repeating what was said.

Cane Growers spokesman Ian Ballantyne delights in throwing around vague comments about the Democrats having our facts wrong on the tariff. I do not want to bag the cane growers; I think they may pay a price for their—

TALK.START.PARA: —Poor old Cheryl had her facts wrong on the Democrats.

—I would like to hear what you are saying, Senator, but I am not sure that it is going to add anything to the debate. I do not want to sink the boot into the canegrowers. BREAK.PARA: Finally, I turn to the politics. It is well known that regional seats will win or lose the next federal election, particularly in Queensland. It would be political suicide for any state or federal government to scrap the single desk selling mechanism. I do not believe that any government would want to commit to that. However, I do believe that when the vote on this bill is known, a number of National Party seats will certainly be at risk. That is what their people are telling me.

Now I turn to Senator Bob Brown's intention, I understand, to vote down the tariff—that is, to vote with the government. I appeal to him even at this late stage to change his mind on that. The sugar tariff is not an environment issue. Not one extra centimetre of land will be allocated for cane assignment through retention of the tariff, but millions of dollars worth of savings will go into the pockets of multinational soft drink manufacturers such as Coca-Cola at the expense of cane farmers and at the expense of the communities which support them.

I wonder at the consistency of Senator Brown's stance. I would like to see him vote to reduce car tariffs on the basis of greenhouse gas emissions from vehicles or vote against textile tariffs on the basis of sweated labour. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a complicated issue. I have put a lot of work into it over the last few weeks. I appreciate the assistance I have been given in that work by representatives of grower organisations, business and conservation interests. The heart of the issue, as other speakers have said, and as it was presented to me very early on, is an apparent trade between the single desk selling system and the 15 per cent or so tariff which the government had removed regardless of this legislation. I will explain this to the Senate. The legislation as I see it is largely about validating the removal of that tariff: it brings it into law. But the government has the wherewithal to remove the tariff anyway, and did so in the middle of this year.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, the single desk selling system is a system by which every farmer gets the same price for the sugar that is produced. Sugar, unlike other agricultural products, is much the same no matter which farm it comes from. In that sense it is different from wool and apples in that sugar is sugar is sugar—the quality does not vary greatly and the purposes to which it can be put are exactly the same.

However, in working through this very complicated situation, it became apparent to me, as the earlier speakers have said, that it was not a trade-off between the tariff and the single desk selling system. The two things were not linked. No-one, including the government, could produce evidence that if one went, the other stayed, or vice versa. It was put to me at one stage that not even if there was a potential threat from the World Trade Organisation would there be intervention if the tariff went and a single desk selling system remained or otherwise.

One thing that was constant, however, and united all interests in the cane growing field is that retention of the single desk selling system. Everybody agrees that it is a good system, everybody agrees that it is fair, everybody agrees that it benefits all cane growers and everybody fears that if it were to be removed, it could lead to a price war up and down the coast, which would be to the ultimate detriment of all concerned. It could even lead to different sugarcane millers having to employ people to go out and try to undercut other millers in the market place, not only here but overseas.

It is worth remembering that some 85 per cent of Australia's sugar is sold on the overseas market and is not affected by the domestic tariff. What is affected by having a tariff of about 15 per cent or $55 a tonne is the domestic price of sugar. It puts it up. This ostensibly means a better price for the cane growers for that 15 per cent of the sugar which is sold in Australia. That in itself has some untoward effects. It means that producers such as Cadbury's in my home state of Tasmania would pay a higher price for sugar than they would if the tariff were to remain abolished. Whether or not that is the case, Cadbury's submits that it is worth $750,000 a year to them not to have the tariff.

However, in following that up, I was not able to find that it would necessarily lead to a drop in the price of chocolates for the consumers out there who might be waiting for that if the tariff were to be permanently abolished. It will mean some rearrangement of the positioning of companies such as Cadbury's, which uses a lot of chocolate, as against producers of other foods. It might give them an advantage in that they will be able to have some price reductions somewhere along the line. That is a moot point.

It does not appear that it is going to help protect chocolate producers, for example, from international competition. However, there is an argument that other farmers are paying a subsidy to sugar growers when there is a tariff in place; and that, for example, people whose produce goes into the canning of fruits, which uses quite a bit of sugar, are having to pay higher prices for sugar. This disadvantages them against very big imports of canned fruit, jams and other produce. So the argument was that having the tariff advantaged cane growers but producers elsewhere in the country would be disadvantaged because their processed product would be sold at a higher price on the market because of the added expense of sugar.

The issue is more complicated than that, but I do not wish to go into it further because I do not have the time. However, farmers were split on the issue. I was lobbied by both groups—the Australian Cane Farmers Association as against the statutory organisation, the Australian Cane Growers Association—with both taking opposite points of view. As I said earlier, the one thing that united them, however, was the single desk selling system being retained. They were split on whether the tariff should remain.

I looked at the environment because, unlike Senator Woodley, I am aware that cane growing has an immense impact on the environment. It is not necessarily a positive impact. The rapid expansion of some 400,000 hectares in the cane growing area in Queensland in the last five years has had major impacts on the natural environment. I can name some of those. It has resulted in pre‐emptive clearing before assignment to sugar growers for expansion of their output has occurred. It has led to the clearing and filling of wetlands. It has led to the clearing of creek banks—that is, no riparian strips have been protected but there has been clearing right to creeks, with obvious impacts on creeks and the ecosystems of the waterways. There has been planting in marginal areas, usually inter‐tidal areas, with acid sulfate problems. We have seen those problems with the tourist development at Hinchinbrook. This acid sulfate problem has occurred where cane growers have moved to clear land below five metres above sea level.

BREAK.PARA: There has been great concern about the use of pesticides on cane farms and about the soil erosion impact of this rapid expansion. I was in the Ayr‐Home Hill area a few years ago and I saw the loss of woodlands in that region consequent upon state and federal government subsidised irrigation, but what pulled me up very rapidly with this expansion of cane growing was the absolute absence of an environmental assessment beforehand. I was told by experts in the field that there were rare and endangered orchids and butterflies in those woodlands and nothing was being done to assess their status. Certainly areas were not being protected to ensure their status but this rapid clearing was occurring.

At the time I felt that governments were extraordinarily remiss to be giving assistance to an industry which had not got its environmental act in order. I am not aware of any environmental authority anywhere in the country that will say the cane growing industry has its environmental house in order. It simply has not.

The threat to more well‐known rare and endangered species like the mahogany glider and the cassowary—extraordinarily important parts of Australian wildlife heritage—is simply only the tip of the iceberg as endangered ecosystems and species, both plant and animal, are faced with the rapid expansion. There is likely to be another 400,000 hectares or so of expansion if the trends of the last five years are to extend for the next five years as far as this so far buoyant industry is concerned.

So I think it is quite remiss of anybody, including Senator Woodley from the Democrats, to say we have no environmental considerations in discussion of this legislation. What is the other appropriate time?

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't misquote me, Senator Brown.
—Senator Woodley, if you do not like that, what exactly did you say?
—I don't like being misquoted.

—I have not misquoted you, but you will have the opportunity to correct the record if you wish to. I am saying, Senator Woodley, that you got up and took me on, on the issue of the environment. I am standing here for the environment because I think it matters. Here is the opportunity to discuss it. If you do not want to, that is fine, but I am bringing the issue up and expanding on it because I think it is important. If we do not discuss it when we are considering legislation like this that affects major industries, when do we discuss it? That is the question I put to you. It is a very valid thing for me to do. That is why I am bringing it up as an issue.
—No hidden agenda?

—Senator Forshaw says, `No hidden agenda?' I am being very open about this. I would have liked the government, or the opposition, or the Democrats for that matter, to come in here and say, `Here's an opportunity for us to do something about the very untoward environmental impacts of this industry. Here's an opportunity to put the challenge to cane growers at least and to put into legislation the concerns of the working group'—not least of which consisted of cane growers—`which investigated this industry so recently.'

BREAK.PARA: Instead of that, we are getting a blinkered response. I am not joining that blinkered response. Because the concerns I have have come down to retaining that single desk system and trying to get an acknowledgment that there is a need for action on the environmental impacts of this expanding industry, both at state level and at national level, I move:
At the end of the motion, add:

TAB.TAB: "but the Senate:

(a) strongly supports retention of the single desk selling system for raw sugar and the use of its associated assignment system to regulate for improved environmental management of the sugar growing industry;

(b) notes that Queensland's Sugar Industry (Assignment Grant) Guideline (No. 2) 1995 makes it a precondition for a grant of assignment that land is "able to be prepared and used for the growing of sugar cane without undue damage to the environment"; and
(c) calls on the Queensland Government to make it mandatory to refuse a grant of assignment for sugar growing on land where any of the following apply:
(i) removal, destruction or damage to mangroves;
(ii) clearing or drainage of natural wetlands;
(iii) where native vegetation has been cleared within the previous five years;
(iv) within 20 metres of a watercourse;
(v) soils are acid sulfate or are below 5 metres Australian Height Datum (AHD);
(vi) removal, destruction or damage to threatened ecosystems or the habitats of endangered species".

BREAK.PARA: That would seem eminent commonsense. I am sure that people concerned for the industry as well as for the environment would accept the double purport of that motion, which is to protect that single desk selling system and at the same time acknowledge and move to stimulate governments into action as far as the extraordinarily rich coastal environment being impacted upon by the sugar cane industry is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike the Democrats, the industry has stuck with their decision to remove the tariff, and they recognise the benefits presented for future growth both in the industry and in world trade. Despite his earlier glowing endorsement of the SIWRP report, it was disappointing to read the same John Allison, General Manager of ACFA, say on 17 October:

SPEECH.PARA: The ACFA has corrected the perception the cane farmers were in total agreement with the recommendations made by the SIWRP.
This was repeated by ACFA Chairman, Warren Martin, on 12 September, when he said:
Australian cane growers are extremely disappointed in the expedient, insidious and uninformed manner in which the federal government supported the removal of the sugar tariff.
It must be remembered it was the industry that conducted its review and made its recommendations—and it was the united industry that told government to support and respect the industry decision.
The latest Senate committee majority report found that dispute over the impact of the removal of the tariff on cane growers has resulted in two important factors being made clear to the committee:
‐ a clear connection between the tariff removal and agreement for the retention of single desk selling of Australian raw sugar, and
‐ that the level of the tariff has for some time been a component for fixing a price which cane growers will receive for sugar sold into the Australian domestic market.
A further factor was that the removal of the tariff was paramount in the decision of the ACCC to reverse their opposition to the merger of the two refineries of CSR and Mackay Sugar.

A further recommendation was for the federal minister for primary industries to hold discussions with the Queensland government for consideration of possible implementation of notional import parity pricing.
The report recommended the introduction of export parity pricing from 1 July this year, which the Queensland government complied with and introduced on 1 July.

However, there have been calls from the industry for import parity pricing, and I believe, as long as this would not diminish the strength of the industry's working party report in the crucial area of single desk selling, the federal and state governments would support this committee recommendation.

NCC clarification would be needed. However, Mrs Smith from the ACCC has already told the commit tee that notional import parity pricing would not be anti-competitive and that this would be the price paid by refiners in a free market for sugar.

The sugar tariff is something that I have been involved with since its inception. In December 1988, when the embargo was removed and the Labor government proposed an ad valorem tariff reducing to 15 per cent by mid-1992, I moved a motion in the Senate that called for the investigation of the need for a tariff in the circumstances of the then corrupt world market. I believed that a tariff was necessary to prevent the corrupted world price for sugar being imported into Australia as the domestic price. This was at a time of massive subsidies to producers in the EU, the US and Thailand, and high tariff barriers with no world trade agreement to control the resultant price and trade distortions. The final result of the Senate inquiry was that the Labor government implemented a tariff of $115 per tonne on raw and refined sugar, reducing to $95 per tonne until July 1992, and $70 per tonne thereafter.

However, 10 months later the Labor government tried to change the rules and accelerate the tariff down from the agreed $70 a tonne to $55 a tonne. Senator O'Chee and some of the other National Party senators crossed the floor to support the industry. It was the Labor Party's wish at the time. That makes it an absolute hypocrisy that the Labor Party now oppose the reduction of the tariff when in opposition—against the wishes of the peak industry body. When they were in government they removed the tariff.

Since the tariff was introduced, many things have changed. Firstly, of course, the industry, through their review, has asked for the removal of the tariffs in the best future interests of the industry. But of enormous significance is the resolution of the Uruguay Round in 1995 and the freeing‐up of world trade. As a result of the Uruguay Round, set reductions in subsidies have been introduced under the terms of the world trade agreement and the lowering of tariffs amongst our main customers and competitors. With sugar the evidence is there to see; it is already happening. As a direct result of the reforms in world trade, there have been increased export opportuni ties. At the same time, the opening up of the Australian industry has seen a 60 per cent increase in production over the last 10 years, compared to 10 per cent elsewhere. The value of cane to Australian farmers has increased by 144 per cent over the last eight years.

With the opening up of world trade as a result of the Uruguay Round and the WTO, we now have the majority of our sugar markets with a sugar tariff of zero to five per cent. Sixty per cent of our sugar goes to Canada, Malaysia, Korea, New Zealand and Singapore—all on a zero tariff, other than Korea with a five per cent tariff. It is true that tariff levels are still unacceptably high in our competitors, but subsidies have come down 12 per cent in the EU and 20 per cent in the US and are scheduled for further reductions. Australia and the Cairns Group put agriculture on the world trade agenda for the very first time in the Uruguay Round and have ensured a further review of agricultural protection in 1999.

The evidence is manifest that Australian raw sugar exports have expanded as a direct result of tariff reductions. There are concrete market gains in our major export markets. In Japan the tariff has gone down from 44 yen a kilo to 15 yen, with sales increases of 19 per cent, from 696,000 metric tonnes to 827,000 metric tonnes over the past four years. The tariff in Korea has fallen from 10 per cent to 5 per cent and exports have increased from 516,000 metric tonnes to 769,000. In Egypt the tariff went from 20 per cent to 5 per cent and Australian exports rose from zero in 1989 to 127,000 metric tonnes in 1994. In Indonesia tariffs have fallen to zero from 10 per cent, opening up exports from zero to 42,000 metric tonnes. In India tariffs have gone from 80 per cent to 50 per cent and sales have gone from zero to 5,000 metric tonnes. And recent sales into places like Bulgaria, Russia and the Middle East flow from tariffs of 5 per cent or zero.

Australia is a major trading nation. The sugar industry exports 85 per cent—soon to be 90 per cent—of its crop. In agriculture generally, only one in five farmers is needed to produce for the domestic market. In the sugar industry, it would be one in nine. As a major exporting country, we have the most to gain from the opening up by other countries of their markets. Our tariff only benefits the 10 to 15 per cent going to the domestic market, whereas the only growth available to Australian cane farmers is from the export opportunities for the other 90 per cent. All Australian rural industries either have a zero or a five per cent tariff. This occurred this decade under the Labor government's tariff reductions. The sugar tariff does hurt these same industries that have no tariff protection and are facing imports. They do not enjoy the 85 per cent export markets of the sugar industry but must remain competitive to remain viable and provide Australian jobs.

No‐one is a greater supporter of the Queensland sugar industry than I am, and I will continue to support and be proud of the highly efficient, world competitive industry that has been created. But future decisions have to be the right decisions to enable the industry to continue to prosper and grow through the only way possible—the export market. History has proven that a divided industry does not thrive; past unity has ensured the industry's success and progress. The industry has had strong, committed and far‐sighted leadership, and giant strides have occurred since the industry undertook its reform program this decade.

The combined industry had the sustained future of the industry in mind when it unanimously endorsed its 74 recommendations, including the removal of the tariff. The achievements and future directions of the industry are contained in the words of the canegrowers' press release last December in support of the review findings. It said:

The good news for growers is that it retains the strengths of our current production and marketing arrangements which have made us one of the world's most efficient, productive and least assisted sugar industries, while providing opportunities for greater flexibility, innovation and local control.

I say to the canegrowers that it is unrealistic for you to try to have us get people to reduce the tariffs that allow your sugar to flow into new international markets while we retain ours. I support the bill because it is the right thing for the industry, and the industry initial ly asked us to do it. The representatives of the industry came down and sought a meeting with Senator O'Chee, me, Larry Anthony and all those that were interested and represented sugar seats. They told us at the time, `We are convinced that in the best interests of the sugar industry the tariff should be removed, so we will not be seeing any other committees, and we are happy if the tariff goes.' That is their word that I took, and I support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 [No. 3] covers essentially three issues. The first issue concerns some basic changes to treatment of electronic components, and this is not contentious, as far as I know. The second is the revenge on Canadian petrochemical provisions. Since the third is the sugar issue, where government wants to drop our tariffs to zero, it is worth considering that the Canadian revenge measure is being launched because the deal with the Canadians was for them to have lower tariffs for our sugar and for us to have lower tariffs for their petrochemicals. The Canadians have not raised their sugar tariffs at all—they have just offered other nations a chance to have the same low tariffs. We are taking revenge for this because it means we export less sugar to Canada.

SPEECH.PARA: Here at home, however, we are quite happy to ignore the sugar industry; there is no apparent gain. What do we get from reducing sugar tariffs? I know that Cadbury and Coke will get a better profit margin since they have said that they will not lower their prices. But this does not mean that there will be any jobs, increase in production or reinvestment of those profits in Australia. These confectionary and soft drink companies are big transnational corporations and their investment strategies are not bound to national considerations. They will invest where it makes the most sense for them. So, there is no apparent gain to anyone except maybe consumers.

Sugar currently costs about 37c per kilo or $370 per tonne on the spot commodity market. The tariff adds 5c per kilo to that cost, bringing it to around 42c per kilo. So for a consumer who pays 1½ times more for the packaging, distribution and marketing of sugar than for the sugar itself, the price of sugar might go from something like $1.06 to $1.01 if the tariff was removed. It might go down by 5c but I would not bet on it.

I also point out that, assuming chocolate is 25 per cent sugar, the value of the sugar in a 250g block of chocolate is about 10c. Reducing the tariff might drop the cost by 1c. A 250g block of chocolate sells in supermarkets for between $2.50 on sale and about $3 at normal price. If a chocolate bar is less than one‐quarter sugar by weight, the significance of the cost differential in sugar is less. Likewise, in soft drinks or other goods the cost differential in the sugar component for the consumer is so small it is entirely swamped by normal store to store variation. Cost of sugar is not a consumer issue. The only people for whom it makes a difference are bulk buyers, such as confectioners.

So very few people stand to win if the sugar tariff goes—mind you, I have seen how much sugar goes into cool drinks; it might make a difference there. On the other hand, we would be likely to see imports coming in from other nations in our region—Thailand, India and China—as well as from more traditional sources such as Malaysia, the EEC and Brazil.

Who would loose? The canegrowers would lose. There are a fair number of them spread up the coast from northern New South Wales. The argument I have heard is that imports would be negligible because the local farmers would just decrease their prices. Unfortunately, reducing prices, where possible, means reducing the profitability of the farm. It is worth noting that those prices may be slightly higher domestically but it is important for them to be kept down on exports. Under pressure economically it would probably mean the growers would try to get by with fewer employees and fewer purchases so workers would lose and small and medium rural towns and cities would lose. Anyone farming in a marginal agricultural area, just starting out or vulnerable to change would possibly loose their farm.

BREAK.PARA: Australia would lose in trade terms. Sure, we would get to boast about being free traders—yet again—but it would have given away any rationale for expecting other nations to lower their tariffs in the future, and we export far more sugar than we use. The EEC has a $797 tariff, the USA has a $506 tariff on above‐quota imports and Thailand has a $332 tariff. Our $55 tariff is already low. There is no requirement under the World Trade Organisation to reduce it to zero. This is entirely the bright idea of our free‐marketeers. It is ironic that this occurs in the same bill where we penalise Canada for lowering their tariffs to other selected nations instead of to just us. Isn't that amazing? I am surprised the government was not more consistent and just lowered the tariff on petrochemicals for everyone instead of just eliminating Canadian preferences.

I will take this opportunity to reiterate that, although I often oppose tariff reduction in this place, the Greens (WA) are not protectionist. We oppose unregulated free trade and would like to see some measure of international if not global regulation to prevent trade advantages built on oppression and exploitation of people and the environment. The scrupulous and well intentioned cannot easily or fairly compete with the exploitative. As several industry groups have pointed out, regulation means everyone must compete on equal grounds. Otherwise, those with a conscience are disadvantaged. If it was not that way, crime, exploitation and so on would not exist.

We favour fair trade where there are measures in place to ensure that the cost of environmental protection and social justice is included in the price of a good. We also favour managed trade, where blocs decide to trade goods of roughly equal value between them so that trade does not result in debt. Development in any practical terms is about creating a better world, and materially about creating wealth through more intelligent use of effort and material. It is not about importing huge amounts of goods and capital and going into debt while depriving one's own citizens of the ability to work. If there is anything valuable about the idea of competi tive advantage in international trade it must be premised on roughly equal trade.

So for me there are several issues so far. The only real advantage to dropping the tariff goes to big confectionary manufacturers. There are some potential drawbacks for rural communities and farmers. There are drawbacks in moving unilaterally to free trade, both in terms of any leverage to get any other nation to lower tariff barriers and in terms of moving towards a regulated fair market system instead of towards a free market, which will provide advantages to exploitation and will economically penalise any nation that acts responsibly towards its environment or its people.

These are basic arguments. There are some specific issues in relation to the sugar industry, however. Sugar is not an environmentally benign product and I will focus on that aspect later as, I am sure, will other senators. It is not a particularly benign product in terms of health, and as a society we eat far too much sugar. Sugar is put into far too many foods where it is not really required as an ingredient. In this case, we have Canegrowers, the peak organisation, supporting the government in eliminating the tariffs. We also have many of their members and smaller canegrower organisations fighting both the government and their own peak lobby organisation.

There has been a certain amount of fear generated about the possibility of eliminating the single desk or making it less effective. We have seen National Party parliamentarians in the House of Representatives cross the floor.

I will start with the last issue first. The single desk is an institution which has broad support from all sides of Queensland politics. Despite rumours, the ACCC has no intention of looking at it, and the National Consumer Council has no power to do so. In spite of any division in the ranks of canegrowers in regard to the tariff, there is no good division whatsoever on single desk selling in the domestic market. I do not think that is at risk. I do not actually believe it is an issue for this debate. I think if it was, you would find Nationals crossing the floor—I was going to say in large numbers, but in whatever numbers they could muster.

I will also point out that the single desk is at least something like what the developing world asked for in the NIEO resolution in the United Nations. It allows some sense of growers working together and getting a fair return, rather than being set against each other by much more powerful distribution companies, in order to drive prices—to the distributor, not the customer—down. It also involves some sense of what is actually required rather than pushing for more and more production to the detriment of all concerned.

There is also the difficult issue of environmental impacts. Senator Brown's second reading amendment seeks to affirm the Senate's support for a single desk and the Senate's belief that the conditions for an assignment grant under the Queensland government, which require that land be suitable for environmentally sustainable sugar production, are good conditions and should be followed. I think this is practical, and I will be supporting Senator Brown's amendment on this.

The environmental consequences of maintaining the tariff, or of removing it, are not easy to determine because there is no direct link. On one hand, the retention of tariffs can be something that results in further expansion of the industry, which may be problematic because so many environmental problems are associated with poorly considered expansion.

On the other hand, the reduction of tariffs can have negative effects in terms of land care. Where a farmer is having a hard time economically and the choice is between doing the right thing in looking after the land and the environment or making enough money to pay the mortgage or other bills, they would often opt for the mortgage. It seems to make more sense to most farmers to have a degraded farm under environmental pressure than to have no farm at all.

One of the critical factors in land care has always been the ability of farmers to have some economic margin. More often than not, poor land care practice is not the result of a lack of understanding. It is dubious as to whether the impact will be good or bad and, of course, economic pressure can come from a number of sources: the farming of land with marginal soil, the impact of drought, flood and climate change, fluctuations on the commodities market and new planting overseas coming on‐line.

Likewise, clearing of land is not necessarily tied to expanding markets. Something like the Sugar Industry Infrastructure Project—SIIP—can result in continuing expansion whether or not there are commercial problems in the industry. So nothing is clear cut except that there are some very bad environmental impacts from current sugar industry activity.

I will put an amendment to try to address the environmental effects, and I will speak at greater length about the problems my amendment seeks to address when I put that amendment. In the meantime, I will bring in a final consideration that has entered my decision on this bill, which is that this is a one‐way process. If the tariff remains, it will always be possible to eliminate it, and I imagine there will be future attempts to do so. If the tariff is removed now there will never be a return to it, no matter what problems may arise subsequently.

In terms of making a good decision, I think there are too many questions to be certain that this is in fact a good thing. If those questions are later answered, the results may be different but, this time, the issue is quite divided. There appear to be very few benefits to the general community as a result of the government's removal of tariffs. There appear to be definite problems and drawbacks. There appear to be no certain positive environmental consequences with either option, and potential drawbacks with either option.

Ultimately, it moves us further in the direction of unregulated free trade. This will have the effect of eroding all measures to protect the environment or community if such measures impose any cost to business. This is a factor which will erode such measures.

Currently, the rapidly expanding producer nations, such as India and Thailand, are expanding with virtually no consideration for the environment or people. Villagers are being `relocated', often forcibly. Other villages are being devastated as sugar farming results in drawdown of ground water in states such as Maharashtra, with the result that communal wells go dry. Herbicides, pesticides and fertilisers, some of which are illegal in OECD nations, are being dumped by chemical companies in these nations, and they are using them without adequate health or environmental training, with devastating consequences for water, land, environment and, of course, for people.

Sugar use is far more intensive than traditional agriculture, and yet these countries are seizing on the option for cash crops and pillaging the land. In a decade or so, we will see these lands stripped of all nutrients and poisoned. But, remember, this is the kind of thing that is encouraged under world free trade.

This is part of the pattern of this particular bill; one of the outcomes. We can talk of Australia being a small market, but we are adding to the demand trend, and that will be multiplied in growth curves projected to continue. Planting will be done on the basis of these projections. When the market is saturated, nations like India will seek to sell anyway. They cannot afford to have such a commitment go unrealised. Sugar prices will drop, and they will be in dire straits economically. This is not a new pattern, but one that has gone on for the last several decades.

I will not be labouring these points, although I have a body of information to which I can point interested senators. I will simply say that this issue of free trade resulting in social and environmental degradation elsewhere is real. It is also real that once these things occur, we see pressure to deny all sorts of rights and benefits and environmental protection in the interest of international competitiveness. That particular phrase has been used to deny everything from environmental protection to native title to industry awards. So, on balance, I will not be supporting the government on this issue. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak tonight, firstly I acknowledge the Ngunnawal people, the traditional owners of the land on which this building stands, and, in recognising them and offering my respects, I draw the attention of all in this place to our special responsibility for and on behalf of them and for all of Australia's indigenous people. This debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , a bill of fundamental concern to them, is taking place without a single indigenous Australian sitting here with a voice and a vote. As the political representatives of all Australians, we are responsible for ensuring that such voices are heard with sensitivity and with respect.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this year, a great majority of Australians, excluding a handful of conservative politicians and their morally bankrupt leader, were willing to step out together on the road to reconciliation. They confronted the truth of our shared past. They reflected with deep sorrow on the dispossession visited on our indigenous peoples. They heard of neglect and of discrimination. Worse still, they heard the stories of families torn apart and of the systematic destruction of the fundamental structures of a rich and ancient culture. The individual stories of abandonment and despair touched the heart of this nation.

BREAK.PARA: We acknowledged these truths in our history and we said we were sorry, and we are sorry for that history, but now we are in the business of making history. We are not looking from a distance at the mistakes of our forebears. We are making choices—choices that we expect our children to live with. We know what we have to do. We know the consequences of ignorance, small‐mindedness, selfishness and blinkered attitudes. How will history judge us? Do we think it is sufficient that we can leave it to our children to revisit our mistakes in 20 years time and then again say sorry? If we fail to act justly, it will not be a matter of sorrow; it will be a matter of collective shame.

We must have a view of the problems that this bill seeks to address that is not clouded by prejudice, by sectional interests or by a wish to conceal or deny and, just as surely, we must not invent problems and then invent devices to deal with them. Native title is not a problem. It is a source of national pride. For indigenous Australians, it affirms their culture, it affirms their traditions and it affirms their very sense of being. For all Australians, it affirms the justness of our law. In confirming the ancient law of our indigenous peoples and the native title that emerges through that law, we affirm justice for all. Let me just repeat those last three words—justice for all—not for one race, not for the wealthy and powerful but for all.

I ask that we proceed from an acceptance of truth—an acceptance of the truth of our history and an acceptance of the truth of our real circumstances. This goes to the heart of matters that will bring us directly in dispute with the government over this bill. This bill represents a series of great Liberal lies. They are lies of a moral, political and constitutional nature. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) promised that his 10‐point plan would deliver certainty yet the bill is probably unconstitutional and, as a result, will see native title cases in the High Court for years and in federal courts for decades.

The Prime Minister promised that the bill would respect the rights of all Australians, but the uncontested and uncontestable legal advice is that this bill is racially discriminatory. In the words of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer), it delivers `bucketfuls of extinguishment'. The Prime Minister and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, Senator Minchin, have said that this bill does nothing more than enact the common law. Yet this bill goes way beyond Mabo and Wik; it goes way beyond those decisions by depriving indigenous Australians of their property rights.

The Australian Law Reform Commission said that the bill, rather than being about the protection and enhancement of native title, should be described as `a pastoral lease enhancement measure'. In some respects, I think this is an unfair description. It is unfair in the way that it purports to represent the interests of many pastoralists. Most pastoralists simply seek to get on with their lives within a framework of legal simplicity and certainty. But the commission's description is an accurate description of what this government has sought to do.

Let us turn to the history of native title. The Mabo decision corrected the great lie upon which this nation had been built. For over 200 years, through the application of the doctrine of terra nullius, Australian law had sought to hide the fact that we were not the first inhabitants of this land. Our law sought to pretend that the indigenous Australians did not have cultures that dealt with issues of land management, nor did the law seek to understand the very special spiritual and cultural attachment of indigenous Australians to this land—their land.

Mabo was the first step in rectifying that blight on our national history. It is a pity that it took a court judgment to force us, as Australians and as legislators, to face up to this issue but ultimately we did and, in a historic compact reached in 1993, the parliament passed the Native Title Act, an act which respects and preserves native title yet allows reasonable use and development of the land to continue. The 1993 act is complex. As a result, it was inevitable that experience would show the need for amendments to the legislation and Labor has been—as is exemplified by the constructive amendments we will move during the course of this debate—willing to support those necessary changes, but so, too, have indigenous Australians been conscious of this.

The Wik decision has presented Australians with an even greater challenge. For the first time, we have been asked to confront the issues of coexistence of land rights. Rights to land is, of course, a very emotive subject. One only has to look at some of the major conflicts around the world to see that and the idea of different communities living side by side, let alone interwoven as contemplated by the principles of coexistence, is a great challenge indeed.

But, unlike the government, we in the Labor Party believe coexistence is a concept that the Australian people are mature enough to handle. After all, despite many of the bleaker moments in our national history, there have been rays of light where Australians, black and white, have learnt to come together on the land that we share. The debate on this bill is a debate about matters of highest principle but it is also a debate about achieving real coexistence for real people on real pieces of land.

Let me turn to the great lies I spoke about earlier on. While they may not be as stark and confronting as the notion of terra nullius, these lies are designed to have exactly the same effect. They are fictions, designed to prevent Australia from coming to terms with the truth of our history—not a black armband view of history nor one that wears a blindfold.

The first lie that must be confronted is that the Wik decision was a win for indigenous Australians at the expense of pastoralists. Nothing could be further from the truth. The Wik judgement confirmed that pastoralists can continue to do on their land what they have done for generations. To the extent that native title is found on pastoral leases, it is subservient to the interests of the pastoralists. To their great credit, and this needs to be placed on the record, indigenous leaders have indicated from the start that they are just as keen as the pastoralists to remove any doubt about the certainty of pastoralists' rights and their right to use the land. Such uncertainty serves no‐one's interests.

To get around what you would expect to be a relatively simple issue, this government has sought to crack a walnut with a sledgehammer, and it has sought to do so in a sneaky, underhand and unprincipled manner. The government has deliberately complicated its Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 to make it difficult for even the experts to understand the full extent of its operation.

The second lie put about by the government is perhaps its biggest. It claims that the government's package is fair and reasonable. The way the Prime Minister and the Special Minister of State (Senator Minchin) have sought to peddle this lie is by comparing this government's legislation with the extreme position of those who irresponsibly argue for the blanket extinguishment of native title. Although this extremist view has been abandoned by the government, albeit reluctantly, it is no benchmark against which to test the legislation. This government, although it has not chosen blanket extinguishment, has chosen something which amounts to only sightly less than blanket extinguishment. To say the package is fair and reasonable because it does not achieve wholesale extinguishment is, I believe, a crude distortion of the meaning of those very well understood words.

But even the position that the government has reached in proposing this bill is fraught with danger. First, the undisputed evidence of constitutional and human rights experts is that this bill is a flagrant breach of Australia's international legal obligations. These same experts are almost unanimously of the view that the bill is inconsistent with the Racial Discrimination Act. The government claims to have legal advice to the contrary but it has been unwilling to test that advice in the public arena. Instead the government—and the Prime Minister in particular—has been unctuous in its criticism of those who claim that the government is acting in a racially discriminatory manner. The Prime Minister has argued that these claims are part of a gross and irresponsible smear campaign.

The problem the Prime Minister has is that people, including senior church leaders, have not levelled these accusations lightly. Contrary to the Prime Minister's perception and the perception he has sought to create, whether Australia is acting in a racially discriminatory manner is not a matter of subjective judgement or public opinion. The benchmarks are provided by the Racial Discrimination Act and the international legal obligations that underpin it, in particular the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. It is against these criteria that Australia, Australians and—particularly—this Senate will be judged. It is against these criteria that the bill has already been judged by legal and human rights experts from Australia and from overseas.

The government, as we know, quite clearly has advice that this bill is racially discriminatory. It has chosen not to release that advice. We in the Senate will continue to seek that advice from Chief General Counsel Mr Henry Burmester on how this legislation breaches both the Racial Discrimination Act and our international legal obligations pursuant to the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination .

The advice is there, yet the Prime Minister and the Special Minister of State have been pretending that there is no such thing. They cannot live with this lie any longer. In living with this lie they have misled the parliament and they have misled the people of Australia for long enough. They must now concede that this bill is discriminatory and must be amended. I hope it will be amended in this place, and I hope it will be amended in the way that the ALP proposes.

We will present some 359 amendments to the government's bill. All of them are aimed at making the ultimate result truly fair and reasonable, not just for pastoralists and miners but also for indigenous people and for the Australian people as a whole. In a very real way, all Australians are stakeholders in this debate. We all have an interest in ensuring a fair and reasonable outcome here, whether we live in urban or regional Australia or rural Australia, whether we are indigenous or non‐ indigenous, whether we have a direct interest in the outcome of this debate or no direct interest at all. All Australia has an interest in ensuring a fair, reasonable and non‐discriminatory outcome.

The third lie that has been put abroad by the government is that its bill is constitutionally valid and will provide legal certainty. There can be absolutely no doubt that this bill will result in long, protracted legal battles that will embroil all the shareholders for a long time. There can be no doubt now that this bill is of extremely doubtful constitutional validity. The government has had the benefit of the advice of a wide array of eminent lawyers who have given evidence before parliamentary committees on this matter. Their advice is powerful and convincing. The bill is said to be based principally on the races power, principally—section 51(xxxvi) of the constitution. As we have been able to elicit during the last few months, a government which bases its legislation on the races power will definitely find itself back in the courts for a long time—and in the highest courts of this country.

The bill's constitutional validity will ultimately be tested against the background of the 1967 referendum. The High Court will do so. That referendum gave parliament the power for the first time to make special laws for Aboriginal people. In the 1960s the government led by Sir Robert Menzies gave consideration to the means of providing the constitutional vehicle for allowing the Commonwealth to pass such laws. It advanced the referendum bill through parliament, on the basis that the power was to be used for the benefit of the Aboriginal race. To quote Prime Minister Harold Holt's second reading speech, `The government would regard it as desirable to secure the widest measure of agreement with respect to Aboriginal advancement.' The bill was passed unanimously by both houses, and it achieved a record 90.77 per cent support from the Australian public. The government now wants to pass legislation which is, unarguably, discriminatory against the indigenous people of this country and it wants to use this very same races power to do so.

Irrespective of the constitutional validity or the technical legalities involved in the interpretation of this bill, there is a very deep moral question involved. How can a government profess to base its law making powers on a purported ability to enact racially discriminatory laws? Not only is this a complete abandonment of the Racial Discrimination Act but it also flies directly in the face of Australia's commitment to international treaties like the one I mentioned earlier. It is downright unethical. During the last few months of scrutiny of the bill, other constitutional problems have been raised by experts. For instance, the bill does not provide just terms compensation, the terms required by the Australian constitution.

Much of the evil in this bill is in its detail. It is impossible to fathom its depths without painstaking research and a great deal of technical knowledge. The government has used the complexity of this bill as a tool. They have banked on the average person being incapable of coming to a fulsome understanding of what its true objectives are. In this way, they have attempted to push and to conceal their three big lies. They have attempted to swamp the opposition and minority parties with the minute detail of the legislation. But we have not been swamped.

The Labor Party has developed a detailed and considered response to the bill, and we have developed our proposals after extensive consultation with all of the stakeholders. Unlike the government, we have listened to all sides and, unlike the government, we have aimed for procedural fairness and honest respect for indigenous rights and an equitable result for all parties. We have tried to get certainty through justice. We have produced a package which is a fair compromise in all of these circumstances. Not one group, of course, can expect to achieve all of their expectations on all of the issues. But we have produced a package of certainty, justice and fairness. We must all be fair. We must be mindful of the historic responsibility that we in this place bear on behalf of all Australians.

Whatever I say about some of the senators opposite, at least some of them have not been hypocrites. Some have refused to join the reconciliation movement. They have refused to apologise for past injustice and they intend to vote for the government's bill. But what of those opposite who stand for reconciliation and who claim to at least acknowledge past injustice? I say to all of them: you will not get a better chance—and you may not get another chance—to act justly, prudently and wisely. I say to all of us in the Senate: let us use our wisdom and our compassion to grasp this great and passing chance to achieve reconciliation in this great nation.
In closing, I commend to all of us in this place the words of Galarrwuy Yunupingu:
Without our rights to land, we will be like a dry leaf dropped from a tree, floating down the river with no direction, no home and no future.
Mr Howard wants to cut us off from our roots and leave us like parasites around the edges of the cities and towns of Australia, living on compensation payments, grieving for our land.

Senators, we do have a historic choice. We can continue a history of degradation and dispossession or we can—and we should—walk together with our indigenous brothers and sisters towards a better and a more just future for all of us.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 constitutes a very important and substantial commitment on the part of the coalition government to write sense and certainty into the Native Title Act. In doing so, the Special Minister of State, Senator Nick Minchin, will deliver real outcomes and tangible results in the form of a workable legislative framework to process native title claims for Aboriginal people and a land administration system geared to facilitate, not discourage, development. This bill is consistent with a raft of other measures in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs portfolio aimed at better improving the conditions and opportunities available to Aboriginal people, who were so poorly served by the previous Labor government. In fact, the outcomes of that government revealed a measurable decrease in services, effectiveness and general health standards for Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: As I and many of my colleagues predicted when the original native title legislation was before the Senate in 1993, the basic administration of the Native Title Act has proved to be cumbersome, costly and totally unworkable. Of the more than 600 claims currently before the Native Title Tribunal, only a single claim has been settled in four years. This is unacceptable and has only been exacerbated by the High Court's Wik decision which found, in essence, that pastoral leases do not necessarily extinguish native title. An obvious balance of interests has to be struck by legislative action. Such a balance is best achieved by a single overarching body of legislation as opposed to a system based on piecemeal litigation—Labor's preferred option.

Historically, the concept of native title has enjoyed the support of this parliament since `antecedent native title' was first proposed in 1988 as part of the founding ministerial statement for ATSIC by the former Minister Hand entitled Foundations for the Future. I was concerned at that time that, should the federal government choose to legislate in this complex area, care should be taken to ensure the intention of the legislation was explicit. At the time I posed a series of questions in the Senate, asking on 27 April 1988:

What does the preamble purport to do? That must be spelt out in clear, precise terms. Further, what will be the effects on mining and industry? Are the proprietary rights of individuals or the Crown in relation to the rights of the States or a Territory affected and, if so, how? What are the constitutional ramifications? Will this improve the position of Aborigines or is the whole exercise merely a political exercise on the part of the Federal Government?

I commended the legal notion of native title as innovative; however, I warned that because such a concept as a native title right was not formally recognised by common law and had never been put into legislation before:
. . . the consequences pertaining to land administration will flow through to the High Court, and that will create very dangerous precedents.

That was in April 1988—four years before the High Court's historic Mabo decision in which a majority of six judges dismissed the common law notion of terra nullius in favour of the legal recognition of native title.

In 1993 the Keating government introduced the Native Title Bill in a bid to answer the host of questions left unresolved by the Mabo decision and to very properly legislate for certainty and predictability. As a senator for the Northern Territory, with over 25 per cent of my constituents being either Aboriginal or of Aboriginal descent, I took a keen interest in the passage of Labor's native title legislation. In my speech in the second reading debate on 15 December 1993, I acknowledged the special concerns expressed to me by Northern Territory residents that the legislation be drafted properly the first time to avoid what most anticipated to be an administrative system set for failure.

Many of the concerns raised by my party colleagues about the seemingly small circle of sectional interests consulted by the Labor government when the legislation was drafted, the very general and ambiguous tenor of the legislation itself, and its divisive nature were dismissed by the Labor Party as they pushed the bill, ham‐fisted, through parliament to satisfy a political, not practical, imperative of the Labor Party. As I said at the time, the legislation was fundamentally flawed.

In the Wik judgment of 23 December 1996, the High Court found that pastoral leases do not necessarily extinguish native title. The findings contradicted assurances given by then Prime Minister Keating, then Aboriginal Affairs Minister Tickner and Senator Gareth Evans on behalf of the Labor Party that the intention of the Native Title Act was that pastoral leases extinguish native title. As Senator Evans told the Senate on 18 December 1993:
It is overwhelmingly likely that when this comes to be formally decided the High Court decision will confirm that properly granted pastoral leases do in fact extinguish native title.
Senator Bob Collins confirmed this intention on 21 January this year, when he told ABC radio:

BREAK.PARA: . . . all I know is that everything that we did previously was based on the assumption, publicly stated on many occasions from the Prime Minister down, that in the view of the Government, the then Government, native title was extinguished on pastoral leases. We now have a majority decision which has taken that judgement and it is contrary to the assumptions that we relied on when we were in Government.
Senator Bob Collins again this morning on radio in Darwin said:
. . . the facts are, and I don't know why people just don't stand up and say it, we were wrong as it happened, as I said by a margin of one judge. But you can't rewrite history.

Labor clearly have no credibility when it comes to native title and have demonstrated they are prepared to play the raw politics of the issue at any cost. Unfortunately, the main casualty of Labor's ineptitude is the broader Aboriginal community. Chief Justice Brennan, a tireless advocate for the Aboriginal cause and a key facilitator of the Mabo High Court judgment, foreshadowed the predicament we now face when he warned in his dissenting judgment in Wik:

It is too late now to develop a new theory of land law that would throw the whole structure of land titles based on Crown grants into confusion. Moreover, a new theory which undermines those doctrines would be productive of uncertainty having regard to the nature of native title.

Our Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 addresses this confusion and uncertainty, and will deliver a workable land administration system equipped to effectively process and administer land claims. I commend the government's second reading speech, the bill and our new amendments—particularly those announced today—for far-reaching detail. It is in all our interests, and especially those of our Aboriginal constituencies, to pass this bill and expedite the processing of the hundreds of claims backlogged in the system.

The notion of a system of Aboriginal land administration and recognition of the special circumstances of Aboriginal people is not new to Northern Territory residents who have lived with the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 for two decades. This act originally provided the facility to transfer freehold title land to Aboriginal people and subsequently set in place the administrative system necessary to manage Aboriginal land. To date, land claimed under the act comprises some 42 per cent—over 560,000 square kilometres—of the Northern Territory, with most other currently available land subject to claim.

The land rights act provides for an absolute veto on development and mining. In the 20 years this provision has been active, only one new mine and the expansion of another have occurred on Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory—an appalling lack of development in some of the most resource rich areas of Australia. Once again, the main casualties are Aboriginal people, most of whom recognise the important links between economic and social self-determination, and the broader Australian community having development held to ransom. Thankfully, the Commonwealth government has recently decided to review the Aboriginal Land Rights Act and the political nature of land councils. I seek leave to have incorporated the terms of reference for Mr John Reeves QC and my initial response to that review.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Native title, as it impacts on the Northern Territory, is well documented in the Northern Territory government's submission to the Joint Committee on Native Title. The bill before us, if passed in its current unamended form, will have no impact on the amount of land able to be claimed in the Northern Territory. Claimable land will remain at about 99 per cent with scheduled land expected to cover less than half a per cent of the territory.

BREAK.PARA: The number of native title claims lodged in the Northern Territory and surrounding waters to date totals 32, covering some 3.5 per cent—49,000 square kilometres—of the territory. The Northern Territory's prime interest in this debate lies in ensuring that native title rights are duly acknowledged and, in turn, in assisting Aboriginal people to overcome social and economic disadvantage whilst, at the same time, delivering a workable land administration system capable of efficiently and effectively serving the interests of commerce and industry, from which all Australians will benefit.

Some of the major players, activists and proponents of misinformation and hysteria have a close link with an international agenda of Aboriginal land issues. We must make sure that an appropriate Australian solution is being developed which, firstly, enhances the local priorities and social needs of Aboriginal Australians and, secondly, does so in the context of our national‐federalist system of Commonwealth, state and territory governments.

It is not too cynical to suggest that the motives of some people are being driven by international ideologies or stupid aspirations for independent Aboriginal government within Australia. The debate that rages outside this parliament is again being fed by the same players from Labor and the Left. As Archbishop Peter Hollingworth so aptly said last week on ABC News:

I'm suggesting that all of us, church leaders and politicians, perhaps might take a cold shower and look at the thing afresh. I don't think these complex and conflicting issues are much helped by what I might call the dewy-eyed sentimentality of people of good will. I don't think that pious generalisations help.

Ignorance, emotion and bias are no substitute for damned hard work and attention to the detail in the legislation itself. Although some may be well-intentioned, the Johnnies-come‐lately to this debate have a vague, distant understanding of this legislation. For the most part they are driving other, totally separate agendas.

Naturally, I have received a number of Northern Territory electorate representations reflecting all sides of the debate. Some of the claims, including those of my own Uniting Church synod, were unsubstantiated, lacked credible argument and relied on uninformed emotion and media rhetoric. In response, I note that the government's bill has four clear objectives: to maintain and respect native title; to reduce uncertainty; to improve the workability of the native title process; and to find a balance among the interests of all parties.

The amendments do not mean the wholesale extinguishment of native title on pastoral leases. No native title rights will be acquired or impaired without fair and just compensation. Our amendments do not overturn the Mabo and Wik decisions. In fact, the bill provides a sensible national framework for coexistence, which is missing from the current Native Title Act.

I have also noticed at the national level that the hyperbole espoused by some Aboriginal leaders and advocacy groups contains four main myths, which are continually rehashed in debate, about the practical applications of this bill. In the interests of a balanced, properly informed debate, these myths must be refuted outright. Firstly: `Coexistence just means access for traditional pursuits.' This actually means a right to have a say in respect of all development on land where there is coexistence. The process and the Native Title Tribunal will create such a bottleneck that most development will be severely impeded.

Secondly: `The bill allows wholesale extinguishment or diminution of native title.' Most of the exclusions to the right to negotiate process contained in the bill—for example, provision of facilities for services to the public, enhance primary production capacity, some limited off-lease activities, non-intrusive exploration and other low impact acts—are all expressed to be subject to the non-extinguishment principle. That is, they can be done but they do not have a permanent effect on native title. If these exceptions were not made, then the only legitimate alternative would be compulsory acquisition, which would extinguish native title.

Thirdly: `The bill should be withdrawn and people should just sit down and conduct reasonable negotiations regarding land use proposals.' In code, this means that, unless you come to an agreement with the native title claimants, you cannot proceed with the project. It is worse than the current right to negotiate, which is almost a veto, because of the cost and time delay implications and changes to an absolute veto. It is naive to suggest that an Aboriginal group with a superior negotiating position because of some statutory process will not take advantage of that strength.

Finally, in response to the statement that the right to negotiate gives native title claimants greater rights than any other land‐holder, it has been said, `Why shouldn't the first Australians be given special rights and privileges to recognise their special place in our society?' It seems extraordinary that in a liberal multicultural society no‐one is challenging the long‐term impact or the logic of making a law that distinguishes one race from the rest. Apart from issues of morality and equality, surely one result of such a law will be to continually emphasise racial difference and to perpetuate division. How can it be in the interests of Aboriginal people to be permanently set apart from Australian society?

The native title legislation we are considering is but one important part of an incredible mosaic of issues and policies before this parliament and the government which impact on the daily lives of Aboriginal people. It is foolish to make native title into a single symbolic `totem‐pole' gesture expected to give solutions overnight. The challenge is to look ahead 10 or 20 years from now and ask: is what we are doing going to contribute to improved living conditions for Aboriginal people and make for better community relationships? Can we guarantee that the implementation and monitoring of actions by Aboriginal communities themselves and government actions be measurable and improve lifestyle and living standards?

To begin to understand such complex issues we must first accept that there are major differences between urban and traditional Aboriginal people and communities that produce strange and necessarily different standards, expectations and dreams—just as in the wider Australian community. We need to recognise that many Aboriginal people are forced to live in two distinct societies with all the necessary obligations to both, whereas the majority of Australians live in one secular society and generally have little appreciation of basic Aboriginal issues.

The two main challenges for Aboriginal people today are in maintaining essential dignity and dealing with the consequences of ghastly violence. Land rights, communication and education—especially literacy—are pivotal to ensuring participation in the decision making process and guaranteeing dignity. To solve the dilemmas caused by violence, our efforts must focus on housing, alcohol and substance abuse, health standards and an appreciation of cultural differences.
