The Howard government has achieved more improvement of services in 20 months than Labor did in 13 years. I commend my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator John Herron, for his ministerial determination to address measurable outcomes, especially future employment prospects through reviews of ATSIC, the Abstudy scheme, CDEP and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.

The Northern Territory government's record of achievement for services to Aboriginal communities stands on its own and is now more than ever obvious in the ballot boxes. In the past four years Aboriginal people have shifted their votes in significant numbers away from Labor and across to the Country Liberal Party—a party which offers the broad-stroke changes and opportunities for the future they want.

The native title legislation and amendments we are now considering will deliver the goods for Aboriginal people. Too many opponents of the legislation and too many headline‐grabbing media commentators are bogged down in a paternalistic, archaic feudalism which would cast Aboriginal Australians back to the Middle Ages.

Whilst I acknowledge that the word `reconciliation' has a different connotation for each one of us based on our own individual historical background, I for one will not be party to inadequate or stupid proposals which only prolong the time it takes for Aboriginal Australians to have an equal and special place in our society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —As I begin tonight, I want to acknowledge the Ngunnawal people, upon whose land we stand tonight during this debate. I also want to acknowledge the presence in the gallery of many people who have come to bear witness to this debate. I hope that they will continue to bear witness in the weeks ahead. I admire their restraint during the previous speech.

SPEECH.PARA: On this occasion I want all senators to learn from history. I know personally the history of the Wik people, and I will spend most of this address telling their story. It has been a large part of my own story. Everyone is shaped by their experiences. That is as true of communities as it is of individuals. My experience of living with and relating to both pastoralists and Aboriginal people ranges over 35 years. Indeed, I have also met with and shared the experiences of pastoralists who are Aborigines.

I had not met an Aboriginal person until I was appointed as a student Methodist minister to the township of Mitchell in the Maranoa in south-west Queensland. In 1962 Mitchell consisted of two communities: one community, mainly white, lived on the western side of the Maranoa River, while an Aboriginal community lived on the eastern side of the Maranoa River in a fringe camp known as the Yumba. In the 1930s the state government had built two rows of two‐roomed, unlined timber houses for Aboriginal people who had been pushed off the land in the surrounding districts by the requirements of the pastoral industry. The Yumba had no reticulated water, no electricity, no garbage or nightsoil collection, no public transport and no telephone.

I began to visit the community and became closely involved in the lives of the people. I remember well families such as the Fosters, the Mailmans, the Swains, the Dodd family and many others. In 1968 and 1969 the people were moved out of the Yumba and into the main township. As Mitchell had been sewered, the Yumba was seen as a health threat to the main township as well as to the Aboriginal people. The houses and humpies were bulldozed to the ground.

In 1985 I was invited by the Aboriginal people to return to the Yumba to share in their celebration of the handing over of title to the reserve to the descendants of the original inhabitants. The old school had been relocated for use as a cultural and teaching facility. It now has electricity, reticulated water and sewerage.

My experience working with the Aborigines of the Yumba was extended in the late 1960s and early 1970s when I lived in Cloncurry in north-west Queensland. The Aboriginal community was physically more integrated into the main township but there were still two communities in many ways. I acknowledge the contributions to my understanding made by such people as Sam Ah Sam, Peter Nardoo, the Lane family, the Cusack family, the Tims family and many others.

However, despite this valuable experience, I acknowledge that 35 years ago I began with many prejudices and at best retained a paternalistic attitude for many years to come. I realise now that prejudice is deeply ingrained in most people. I thank the Aboriginal people because, despite my ignorance about them, they have never given up on me. The road to coexistence and reconciliation is a long one and I am grateful to many Aboriginal people who have walked that road with me.

The collective experience of the churches is similar to my own. For generations no other group of people in Australia cared whether Aboriginal people lived or died, apart from the churches. In recent years it has been fashionable to blame the churches for their at times appalling attitude towards Aboriginal culture and religion. However, this ignores the fact that it was only the churches who provided support, protection and refuge to many of those Aborigines who survived the genocide perpetrated against them by sections of the white community.

The Wik people of Cape York illustrate the history of Aboriginal‐church relationships very well. The Presbyterian Church established mission stations at Old Mapoon in the last century and earlier this century at Aurukun. In 1977 the Uniting Church, of which the Presbyterian Church became a part, took over the administration of those communities.

Wik itself is a generic term meaning speech or language and is used to describe a number of diverse groups which inhabit the western side of Cape York Peninsula. In the 1950s the world's richest deposits of bauxite were discovered in the area. In 1957 the Comalco Act was passed by the Queensland government, which excised nearly 8,000 square kilometres of land from the mission reserve. The church eventually succumbed to pressure from the Queensland government and Comalco and abandoned the mission. However, a number of people refused to move from Old Mapoon until eventually the Queensland police forcibly removed the remaining residents from Old Mapoon to New Mapoon—near Bamaga on the tip of Cape York—on 15 November 1963.
It is worth putting on record the eyewitness account of one of the women who was moved from Old Mapoon. Her name is Rachael Peters and she describes her experience like this:

We're the ones that were moved out by police, by gunpoint, (on) that boat they sent for us . . . sneaked in on us in the night . . . they came from Thursday Island. We were really sad, but we just had to go because they told us we were going for questioning. At the Bamaga wharf they told us there were seven houses waiting for us to walk in and light the stoves. And when we arrived in Bamaga there were no homes. We were just standing out in the streets like a mob of cattle with nowhere to go. This is what they do, but the world doesn't know. People don't know how we were treated. They destroyed the homes, burnt them down you know. And I seen all the burning down of the homes, the church . . . it was destroying our culture, our lives.

However, that 8,000 square kilometres was not enough for these mining companies. In 1975 the Queensland government passed the Aurukun Associates Act, which excised another great slab of Aboriginal land from the Wik people. This was challenged in the Supreme Court and the High Court by the Wik people in the name of Wik elder Donald Peinkinna. The Uniting Church provided him with legal and other support. The Aboriginal people won in the courts but the Queensland government appealed to the Privy Council. The Privy Council found in favour of the government on the grounds that the Director of Aboriginal and Islander Advancement was under no obligation to make any particular provision for the community.

In 1978, after having administered the Aurukun and Mornington Island communities for decades, the Uniting Church was given three weeks to quit those communities so that the Queensland government could take over and stop what it decided were dangerous gestures toward self-determination for the Wik people being supported by the church. The parallels with last week's comment from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) indicating that the churches should not speak out on Wik are startling.

Prominent in the leadership of the Presbyterian Church at this time was Reverend Dr John Brown, Reverend Jim Sweet and Reverend Gordon Coutts. The community was outraged by this action of the Queensland government and put the following message to the Moderator of the Uniting Church in Queensland in a telegram from the Mornington Island outpost:

COUNCIL AND COMMUNITY BITTERLY DISAPPOINTED BY THE COMMONWEALTH SIDING AND AGREEMENT WITH THE STATE STOP WE SAY ONE MORE TIME WE DO NOT WANT STATE CONTROL BUT THE CHURCH WITH FEDERAL ASSISTANCE STOP WE ASK THE CHURCH TO STAND BESIDE US IN THIS

The church at the time was accused of being corrupt and controlled by radicals and communists. The late Professor Roly Busch, then Moderator of the Queensland Synod, replied in a letter to church members dated 20 March 1978 where he said:

Some have referred to a `bunch of ratbag socialists' in the Uniting Church in Queensland. We who are nourished in the brilliant insights of the Bible, and who are the inheritors of Calvin, Knox, Cromwell and Wesley, need no political parties, socialist or otherwise, to form our minds on the proper liberties of Christian subjects.
In the ringing words of the forbears of one of our traditions—
`In very truth we fight not for glory, nor riches, nor honour, but for that liberty which no true man relinquishes but with his life.'
The people of Aurukun and Mornington Island are our brothers and sisters in Christ. They ask for support and help at this time. We can do no other than stand with them on this issue.
That was from the head of the Uniting Church in the late 1970s.

But even this was not enough for the Queensland government. In the early 1980s John Koowarta, on behalf of a group of Wik people, applied to purchase the cattle station at Archer River not far from the Aurukun township. The transfer of the pastoral lease was refused by the government on the basis that government policy opposed proposals to acquire large areas of additional freehold land or leasehold land for development by Aborigines or Aboriginal groups in isolation. In other words, these Aboriginal people were not allowed to own land—their traditional homelands!

John Koowarta challenged the government through the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The Queensland government challenged the Racial Discrimination Act in the High Court and they lost the case. However, the government, in a fit of pique, made sure that John Koowarta would not benefit from the High Court decision. They changed the title of the lease from a pastoral lease to that of a national park. It seems there is nothing the Queensland government will not do to prevent the Wik people obtaining justice. That is why the Australian Democrats will not add to this shameful record by agreeing to this appalling legislation.

It is not only Aborigines, however, who should fear this legislation. It will provide no certainty to pastoralists either. I understand the feelings of pastoralists, who may believe that they have been singled out by the Mabo and Wik High Court decisions. However, I believe the real threat to pastoralists is from mining companies.

I am amazed that the government seeks to reduce native title holders' rights to negotiate with mining companies to that of pastoralists. If you ask Queensland grain growers or dairy farmers at Mount Larcomb in Central Queensland or those farmers whose properties have been damaged by coalmining in Central Queensland about their experience of dealing with miners, they would soon tell you. I challenge the federal government, which claims to be the friend of farmers, to introduce legislation to upgrade the right to negotiate for farmers so that they could have some equity in their struggle for justice against mining companies, instead of reducing the rights of Aborigines.

The Australian Democrats stand ready to defend the delicate agreement which was struck between the key stakeholders in 1993. We concede that the Native Title Act is not a perfect piece of legislation. In the areas of representative bodies and the streamlining of applications and agreements there is now widespread acknowledgment that some adjustment is necessary. We do not believe, however, that it is open for governments with failing popularity to `beat up' people's fears, talk down the value of their properties and rationalise their own unlawful behaviour. Land price devaluations have not eventuated, people's backyards have not been taken from them, and mining development and exploration have not ground to a halt.

The Wik decision should have been an opportunity for further advancement in the cause of reconciliation. In clear terms the High Court stated that the sharing of the land—indeed, coexistence—is possible. What greater statement of reconciliation could there be and a clear and unambiguous indication that it is possible for indigenous and non-indigenous Australians to share the land? But the High Court also said that, where it is not possible, pastoral rights will prevail. To its discredit, the Howard government has taken this statement by the High Court and used political opportunism to reassert terra nullius, although now they refer to it as Tim Fischer's bucketloads of extinguishment.

The very sad thing about this legislation is that it is unnecessary. It is not necessary to extinguish native title to give certainty to pastoralists. It is not necessary to risk years of court cases over this. An even sadder thing is to see the ALP collapse their principles to support the validation of intermediate period acts. In simple words, this means they will not in this place tell the truth, which is that the Goss Labor government attempted to override native title on behalf of mining interests and that that attempt was wrong. We will call them on this during the committee stage of the bill. If we passed this bill as it is, Australia would become an international pariah.

Tonight I have outlined my history of association with Aboriginal people in Queensland which began in Mitchell 35 years ago. I have been enriched by this association. I am proud to be able to stand here tonight as the Democrats' native title spokesman and try to bring some justice for Aboriginal people. The Wik people are real people, not some legal concept, and they deserve justice like any other Australians. I call on all senators to use every ounce of intelligence, conscience and resolve that they have in the coming weeks to change the 10-point plan into a plan for fairness, equity and justice, and not pass a bill based on discrimination and injustice. If we cannot amend this bill to remove its fundamental injustice, the Democrats will not vote for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —John Howard's Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 is an outrage. We will be spending at least the next two weeks in the Senate trying to amend a bill that is an affront to human rights, an affront to the community, an insult to our indigenous peoples and at the end of it all a bill which, if it remained the way it is, would be extremely vulnerable to challenge in the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation primarily deals with native title rights. However, as we know, native title rights are inextricably linked to reconciliation and to justice. Over the past 30 years the historic struggle of our indigenous people has exposed to the wider community the profound interrelationship of land, justice and mutual respect. The Labor Party recognises this and has worked hard towards genuine reconciliation with Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders. These achievements are at risk of being undone.

Our response as a nation to the issue of native title rights is critical in terms of our standing and reputation as an inclusive and democratic society where the rights and interests of all our people are given equal weight and recognition. It is not only our international reputation that is at stake here but also our own value system as a people who believe in a fair go for all.

The legislative path towards reconciliation began with the powers given to the Commonwealth under the 1967 referendum to pass laws and expend funds for the benefit of Aboriginal people. Then came the enactment of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, which gave force to the external affairs power through our international treaty obligations to address racial discrimination. Since then this parliament has worked to improve the health, education and general wellbeing of indigenous people. The passage of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 brought a significant shift away from paternalism and the welfare mentality towards greater empowerment and self-determination for our indigenous people.

The Native Title Act 1993 was introduced to provide legislative recognition of the Mabo High Court decision, which profoundly changed the structure of land tenure in Australia. The legislation enabled indigenous people to access an alternative and less adversarial means of proving title on lands where native title has yet to be extinguished by later grants or land use in the post‐colonial era. These three defining acts of parliament—the Racial Discrimination Act, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act and the Native Title Act—are fundamental milestones on the long road towards understanding and reconciling ourselves with the past and providing a positive future for all Australians.

The debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 will also be defining. But, if it is passed in the form that the government proposes, we will be abrogating our responsibilities to enact laws for the benefit of all Australians. It will bring shame on the Australian nation.

John Howard and his government have blindly failed to accept and understand that native title rights are a reality. Native title rights are here to stay; they will not go away. The High Court of Australia has recognised native title rights as fundamental legal property rights. As such, they should be respected and protected in the same way that property rights of non-indigenous Australians are respected and protected.

This debate tells us more about the coalition government and its leader than perhaps any other issue that has been brought before this parliament since the election. More than anything, the Native Title Amendment Bill is racially discriminatory because it takes rights away from one group on the basis of race—and you cannot put it any simpler than that.

This government knows that that is the truth because its own legal advisers have told it so. But it has chosen to ignore that advice. If the Senate accepted the legislation as is, without amendment, its provisions would extinguish bucketfuls of native title rights and, in other cases, diminish native title rights.

This bill is a product of John Howard's lack of leadership. It is typical of his stock in trade—lowest common denominator, opinion‐poll driven politics. The government is not only deeply hostile to the concept of native title but deeply ignorant of the operation of the existing native title legislation. The result is the bill before us; born of prejudice, confused, unconstitutional and divisive, it provides no solution, let alone certainty.

Of course, the promise of certainty is the platitude that the government keeps mouthing. No, Mr Acting Deputy President, this bill will bring shame to John Howard—and I think it will bring shame to all of us.
It is worth examining what Mr Howard said, what he promised, in regard to native title before the 1996 election. The coalition's pre-election policy says:
The Coalition approach to Aboriginal land rights is based on the following
a) the fact of Native Title where it has survived;
b) the Constitutional protection given to all property interests against Government resumption without compensation;
c) the prohibition of racially discriminatory measures or laws; and
d) the special relationship between Indigenous people and land which is at the core of Indigenous culture.
It further says:
In Government, the Coalition will:
a) retain the Native Title Act; . . . and
c) respect the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act.

How does the bill before us deliver on those promises? This legislation does not respect the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act, and it does not maintain the core principles of the 1993 Native Title Act. As for the so-called fairness on which the coalition's approach to native title rights is based, the words of that pre-election pledge hold no more substance than the stream of other broken promises John Howard has left in his wake since being elected Prime Minister.

I am sorry to have to say to the Senate that the role that John Howard has played in this debate on native title rights has been contemptible. I am sorry to have to say to the Senate that he has promoted division. I am sorry to have to say that he has tried to exploit fear and ignorance. But what other conclusion can any reasonable person draw from the spectacle of the Prime Minister of Australia appearing on national television and holding up a map of which 78 per cent was marked and coloured brown and saying these words:

. . . the Aboriginal people . . . have the potential right of veto over the development of 78 percent of the land mass of Australia. Now, that is a very simple message. I think the Australian people will understand that message.
That is what the Prime Minister said.
Page 15 of Mr Howard's own explanatory memorandum to this very bill nailed that very public untruth. It says:
The right to negotiate was not a veto.

In making that statement on the 7.30 Report , the Prime Minister debased his office. It was a divisive, a vengeful and a misleading message to the Australian people. With his geography lecture, Mr Howard was attempting, I believe, to incite fear and raise community tensions. In fact, the Prime Minister's map is as flawed and as inflammatory as his legislation.

The opposition will do all it can to prevent this legislation passing in the form that the government proposes. The Australian Labor Party believes that there are certain principles that you cannot back away from; there are certain principles on which, unequivocally, leadership is required.

Mr Howard has had ample opportunity to show leadership and vision, but he either will not or cannot deliver. This country is suffering because we have a limited Prime Minister whose whole political career has been driven by one goal—the goal of becoming Prime Minister. Many of us in the Labor Party admire his doggedness and his determination in his almost 25‐year struggle to achieve that goal. I can say that I do. But he achieved that ambition in March last year. The point is that his whole focus was on getting into office, there was not a thought about what he would do once he got there, and that is the problem. All John Howard's efforts were concentrated on the glittering prize of becoming Prime Minister. Beyond that, he had no plan, no vision, no sense of destiny for the Australian people and no sense of destiny for where Australia ought to go.

I have got to say that I fear we will wait in vain for John Howard to show the high level of leadership which the nation demands on this issue. It really says it all that Mr Howard would even consider an election on race issues. He has reflected in public that he thinks Australia is mature enough for a Wik based election. I think it is appalling that anyone could contemplate such an election. He would divide our country in the most crude terms—it would be the bush versus the city; black versus white.

The Labor Party could quite easily have adopted a destructive approach to this bill. We could have simply tried to vote this piece of legislation down. We have not taken that path. We have taken a constructive approach; a painstakingly constructive approach. Our comprehensive amendments are designed to effect a real compromise. This process must deliver reconciliation in a real way—not in a merely theoretical way. All stakeholders must understand that their wish lists are not fully achievable. But we have, through extensive consultation, achieved a package of proposals that will bring equity and fairness to this process.

This debate and its outcome will be judged by history. Unlike the Prime Minister, who refuses to accept the reality of the Mabo judgment, we do have the vision to see how history would judge this legislation if it went through unamended. Unlike Mr Howard, we believe that certainty and justice can be achieved through native title rights. Let me be absolutely clear: I would be ashamed to be a member of this parliament if we allowed this legislation to go through unamended. Let us not forget that John Howard promised to govern for all Australians. Let all of us never forget our fundamental responsibility to indigenous Australians. We will not cave in and allow this grave injustice to be perpetrated on them. I urge all senators to follow suit.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Native Title Amendment Bill, which aims to implement the 10‐point plan based on the principle of non‐extinguishment and fitting within the parameters of the High Court Wik decision. The lease schedule attached to the bill confirms where exclusive possession has extinguished native title. This schedule covers some 7.7 per cent of Australia's landmass.

PARA.EMPHASIS: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Boswell, will you resume your seat. I would ask the attendants to remove those people. Can I say that all interruptions from the gallery are disorderly and people will be removed if they continue to disrupt the process of the Senate. I call Senator Boswell.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not need the protection of the chair. I will continue on no matter what they do. The title schedule covers some 7.7 per cent of Australia's land mass. In addition, the bill confirms that freehold has extinguished native title on an area of some 14 per cent. Altogether, some 21 per cent of the Australian land mass is unavailable for claim, leaving some 79 per cent open to native title negotiations, including half the state of Queensland. Aboriginal land interests already include 15 per cent of the nation's land, some 117 million hectares, and a billion dollar land fund to acquire more.

BREAK.PARA: This bill will go some way to clearing up the mess left by the inadequate 1993 Native Title Act. Primary production activities are not subject to the right to negotiate and the higher threshold test aims to sift out the ambit and spurious claims from the genuine. While there is a sunset clause of six years to pursue claims through this legislation, common law rights remain.

As the National Party leader in the Senate, I wish to dispel several myths about native title and the bush. The first is that farming families are opposed to co‐existing with Aborigines. That is false. Let me quote the NFF's Don McGauchie:
The farmers of Australia do not want to abolish native title . . . The farmers of Australia do not oppose the concept of coexistence.

For generations black and white families have coexisted in rural Australia. They have sat down together and made agreements about access. White families have been given precious knowledge of Aboriginal stories and sacred sites.
Both Pat and Mick Dodson have acknowledged this. Pat Dodson told the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title:

In reality many Aboriginal people have co‐existed with pastoral owners and have been able to retain their cultural identity and to express that identity without interfering with their property rights or their pastoral property interest.
Mick Dodson said:
. . . co‐existence was, and in many parts of the country today still is, the daily reality on pastoral lease land.
That was one of the Dodson brothers.
What we have seen in many far‐flung isolated pastoral leases is an accommodation of two cultures at a grass roots level. John Cobb of the New South Wales Farmers' Federation told the committee:
. . . we have never had a problem negotiating on a one‐to‐one basis for access rights . . . No Aboriginal group has ever found it necessary to go to court over it.
The twin icons of the bush and the dreamtime have become intertwined and, as another pastoralist described to the committee, `interdependent on each other'.

The concern expressed by many land holders, both black and white, is that their ability to self‐manage their co‐existence is being taken away from them. This is done through the unwieldy size and ambit of claims and through having to deal with representative Aboriginal bodies rather than with local people.

The second myth about farming families is that the native title debate can be expressed as `They are all big foreign owned companies who make heaps of money on huge areas of public land and they should be forced to share it.' Ninety‐five per cent of the 1,540 individual enterprises not on lease schedule in Queensland are run by families. This covers some 53 per cent of Queensland. Around two per cent have some foreign ownership and about 10 per cent have some corporate ownership, mostly from super and insurance companies.

These families have weathered the toughest decade of drought and adverse market factors including high debt and interest rates. Those who have survived face the future afresh with few reserves—either financial or physical. But their spirit carries them on bulwarked in the past with the support of city and church.

Secondly, they do not operate on common land but have purchased their property which is alienated crown land. It is at once their home and their business—a business which slips into overdraft once school fees and overheads are paid. And yet there are calls now for further compromise and parleying over native title. What more can the bush offer?

The third myth is that farming families stand to gain from this bill while Aborigines will lose. This fallacy stems from a lack of understanding of the processes in the bill regarding acquisition of native title and lease upgrading. Farming families have lost what they were told they had in 1993—exclusive ownership. They must now struggle with a two-title system on one piece of property. Any upgrading under this legislation has to proceed against very difficult odds—through both state parliaments and the Senate, for starters. No doubt it will also have to survive a variety of legal and political challenges. A leaseholder must also have a reason to change the condition of lease and land use before even beginning the process. And the lessee must have the financial wherewithal to pay for the upgrading. It is not just a gift or a handout. Upgrading is simply not an option for most graziers for all these reasons. Even where it is an option, it will be very difficult to achieve.

Traditional lease upgrading is a standard ongoing practice in land tenure management to enable responses to changes in markets and technology. Farmers themselves have been victims of the national interest in land acquisition for infrastructure, other development and even the breaking up of vast properties to make them into smaller ones. Grazing properties have been cut up near Ayr in Queensland to open up the country to sugarcane production. Where 400 acres once supported 30 or 40 head of cattle, it now produces some 12,000 tonnes of sugarcane at $30 a tonne. That means lots of jobs in mills and support services. It means exports that help black and white in regional in Australia. Black and white work together not only on properties but in the council work forces, mills, abattoirs, railways and so on.

They know which side their bread is buttered on—the same side. It is in the interests of all Australians that our country be prosperous and job creating. That is the only way out of poverty. That is the way to help the disadvantaged.

The fourth myth about native title and the bush is that anyone with reservations about native title is racist scum. That is absolutely false. If the Dodson brothers can give credence to pastoralists for being part of a daily co-existence, why can't the rest of Australia? They are not racist scum. They are ordinary Australians. They want to support their families like the rest of us. They want to make sure their land tenure is secure, like the rest of us. They want to know what they can or cannot do on their property, something the rest of us take for granted. They want to pay out their mortgage, plan a future and contribute to earning export dollars. Their dreams are our dreams and they too wish to live in harmony with their neighbours. They are not unduly concerned about Aboriginals coming to fish and hunt. That is manageable if it is worked out locally.

What few people seem to realise is that many native title crusaders equate native title with much more than traditional pursuits, and that is alarming to rural families whose property is barely able to keep one family, let alone meet the demands for economic native title rights.

Attempts to define native title at the parliamentary committee hearings met with a range of answers, from native title being a state of mind and heart, to encompassing contemporary rights such as the right to build infrastructure and participate in commercial ventures to assist economic self‐sufficiency. Father Frank Brennan said that housing `may be a part of contemporary native title rights. People do live in houses nowadays.' He also suggested excisions of a living area.

The Catholic Commission for Justice, Development and Peace stated on Monday that the best solution is one which takes into account land management practices, and that the right of indigenous people to `participate and develop an economic activity should be recognised'. That is not a reference to fishing or collecting wood for a didgeridoo. Tracker Tilmouth told the native title committee:

What we are talking about is an economic framework that indigenous people have to sustain themselves which is not being considered. Hunting, gathering and so forth used to be all right in the old days. It has changed a lot now.
So those rights are a greater list of rights now.

The Aboriginal Legal Rights Movement supported the Indigenous Land Corporation's submission to the parliamentary committee, stressing that native title does not simply equate to another form of title. The native title claimants have the right to decide what they will do and what they will not do with their rights and interests.
The Bulletin Morgan poll released this week produced some very interesting results. As reported in Monday's Sydney Morning Herald:
By far the largest number of respondents, 81 per cent, agreed that farmers should be guaranteed that they could use the land they leased as needed.
That should really hit home to senators considering their vote on this legislation.

There is no ground swell of public support for native title to mean interfering with the managing of farming family properties. Activists are wrong if they think the nation supports a native title which means more than traditional pursuits of farming land. It does not.

With regard to the right to negotiate on mining and pastoral leases, Labor proposes to allow graziers nominal disturbance claims rights while native title holders can negotiate a piece of the action. Who is being discriminated against here?

Farming families are told that, where there is inconsistency between native title and pastoral lease activities, pastoralists' rights prevail. But there is no way of working out what the point of inconsistency may be without knowing what native title is in every local case. Even Father Brennan admitted before the committee that:
Everyone concedes that the interchange between common law and native and pastoralists' rights is an area of uncertainty.

Farmers are at the mercy of the courts, who will tell them whether a native title activity is inconsistent with pastoral activities. Since when has a court run a family property and survived to tell the tale?

There are plans in Queensland, New South Wales and Western Australia to diversify, to spread economic risk of further droughts and low commodity prices. Should native title holders be given the chance to negotiate whether a farmer can grow grapes where before he had cattle? As the New South Wales farmers told the native title committee:

What we have tried to explain more than anything today is how absolutely essential it is for us to diversify . . . we have had forms of agriculture happening in the western division that could not have happened 50 years ago. Incredible changes have taken place, and incredible changes must take place in the next 30 years. To say that we have to stay straight‐out pastoral holdings means that, firstly, they will go backward and, secondly, some of them will not survive. The only chance for the western division to be part of a viable community in the future is for those regions that can do so to diversify whenever necessary.

Unless this bill is passed, farmers fear property management will be stuck at 1997. What are the chances of flexible responses to markets and technology if there is to be a minefield of negotiations with city lawyers getting into the act? A young farmer looking to the future told the committee:
The frustration of sitting on top of a mountain of potential with all the enthusiasm being tied up inside and of being hamstrung by a system that has lost touch with reality is taking its toll.
He said:
The system, the way I see it, is a perfect recipe for them and us.

What will happen to the relationships between local black and white families? It is already happening: people crossing the streets to avoid talking with old friends. This system is damaging our oldest practitioners of coexistence. The High Court decision has left an ironic and bitter legacy in rural Australia—pitting white against black.

Where will the real loss lie if we fail to replace the inadequacies of the 1993 legislation? It will not just be the end of reconciliation in the bush. It will put at risk the investment environment which supports the job security of blue‐collar workers in regional Australia—black and white.

The Australian editorial only the other day talked with dismay about how there is no longer a vision of a way forward for Australia to break the back of unemployment, to grow and prosper and to make all our lives better. Well, there are two things which the country excels at, which we are good at and where we have a natural advantage—mining and primary production. Plenty of factories have closed down under competitive pressure. They were the job providers of the past. The new jobs will come from primary production and downstream activities in food processing, which is the largest employer of blue‐collar workers in the country.

We must not handicap our chief advantage and leave future generations of school leavers with a quagmire of negotiations over the enmeshment of native title and pastoral activities, with only one side knowing what native title means and only one side knowing what running a property means. How many Solomons sitting behind court benches do we have in this country? Not nearly enough, I would suggest, to see this through.

I am tired and the people out west are tired of hearing only one side. It is outrageous that academics should be threatening the equivalent of a Vietnam protest and peppering their indignation with falsities about the positions of pastoralists. I am also struck by how unoriginal they are. I have many letters from academics, all nearly identical. Can't they think for themselves? Why do they parrot what others have told them? I suspect it is because they do not really understand the issue.
Why hasn't the group called Women And Wik accepted the invitation of the Regional Women's Alliance to come and talk to them? Why hasn't it even replied?

Instead of writing to me about all these so‐called wealthy pastoralists out to deny Aborigines their rights to traditional access, on which they are wrong on both counts, why don't they write and ask that their halls of learning be removed from the schedule of leases? I would be happy to move such an amendment. Why doesn't Labor move the 356th amendment to take union offices and facilities off the schedule?

It is inconsistent to support the farmhand campaign one day and to deride the bush as greedy, racist scum intent on land grabs the next. I do not recognise these people so described. I do not know such a class of people in Australia, but I do know the people in the bush and I know that there is a huge fracture developing and splitting the icons of the bush and the Dreamtime. Unless this legislation is passed as a beginning, those icons unique to Australia will be unable to function properly. Built on independence, they will not survive without it and there will be nothing that the churches, the academics or even the government will be able to do about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Since first devised, the Howard government's Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 has been an exercise in deception, discrimination and ultimately dispossession. The government has continually misled the Australian public on this bill. For example, various ministers, especially Senator Minchin, have said time and time again that there is no extinguishment contained in this legislation. Well, Senator Minchin, the game is up.

SPEECH.PARA: By now everyone in this chamber should know that the High Court held in Wik that, when pastoralist and native title rights are inconsistent, the pastoral rights will prevail to the extent of the inconsistency. The High Court did not say that such an inconsistency would extinguish native title. Yet, by virtue of sections 23F, 23G and 23I of the government's bill, native title will be permanently extinguished in such circumstances.

As Senator Minchin well knows, this is not the only form of extinguishment made possible by the Native Title Amendment Bill. The extinguishment may not always be as obvious as a clause or a division. It may work via a schedule, a sunset clause or it may require the cooperation of a state or territory government. Nevertheless, it proposes massive dispossession of Aboriginal people.

In my state, the Premier, Richard Court, has claimed that senior public servants in the so‐called Mabo unit—the one which was involved in the belligerent, wasteful and divisive Native Title Act case—were key players in drafting the Commonwealth's Native Title Amendment Bill. Simultaneously, we have seen all around Western Australia the state government enacting Crown to Crown grants in order for this form of extinguishment to take effect as soon as this bill is passed. Make no mistake, this is a concerted attack on Aboriginal people by state and Commonwealth governments alike.

The government, and in particular Senator Minchin, has displayed a level of unprecedented arrogance and paternalism in the debate around this bill. The very fact that consultation has not continued with indigenous Australians is the absolute epitome of this. I spoke to Robert Bropho, who is an elder from the Swan Valley Nyungar community, and he said that there is just no evidence of consultation with the community from his viewpoint—no effort at all from the government to try to help people to understand what the issues are.

BREAK.PARA: The fact that this is such a fundamentally piece of legislation renders the government's arrogance even more reprehensible. When the finest lawyers in the country say the bill is legally and constitutionally flawed, the government says they are wrong. When the churches declare the bill unfair, they are wrong. When Amnesty International says the bill breaches human rights obligations, they are wrong. When thousands of people gather around the country to ask the country to withdraw the bill, they are wrong. When British politicians declare the bill discriminatory, they are wrong. When the Greens expose the injustice of the physical connection test in this bill, we are wrong. And, of course, when Aboriginal people say that the measures contained in this bill will destroy their culture, they are wrong. Senator Minchin knows better than all these people and I think this is taking paternalism just a tad too far.

From here on, government senators are on warning. The Greens and the other non‐government parties have gone through this bill with a fine‐tooth comb. We know every avenue of extinguishment, every attempt to scale back rights, every clause which makes it difficult for Aboriginal people to exercise their land rights. If you insist on reviving the era of unutterable shame that blighted Australia for so long, you will forever stand condemned as the architects of this revival.

This whole debate has been characterised by an inability on the part of the government to recognise the distinct and unique relationship between Aboriginal people and the land. It has been characterised by a government that views native title purely as an inconvenient property right to be read down in line with the narrowest possible interpretation of common law. There is one word for a policy approach which seeks to absorb Aboriginal cultural imperatives. That word is `assimilation' and assimilation is really only a euphemism for cultural genocide.

It is a policy which harks back to the dark, shameful days in Australia's history when the answer to the so‐called Aboriginal `problem' was to blend indigenous people and culture into European‐based society. When this government diminishes and extinguishes the `special' property rights of Aboriginal people, it diminishes and extinguishes Aboriginal culture and, in my opinion, it diminishes Australia. As Peter Yu, from the Kimberley Land Council, said recently:

Extinguish our title and you extinguish our people. Remove or diminish our title rights and our culture cannot remain like a parcel of possessions carried around by each individual indigenous person. It collapses and dies.

What sort of a Prime Minister says, on a public issue of such vital importance to the character and future of this country, that the public is `not terribly interested' and that the best thing we could do is to simply get this debate `over and done with' and move on to issues of greater importance? Well, Mr Howard, there is no issue of greater importance to Australian society than how we, as non‐indigenous Australians, reconcile with the people whose land we have stolen and whose society we have decimated.

Everything we have as a society—our wealth of resources, our comfortable and privileged position in the world—has been achieved at the expense of the ongoing suffering and dispossession of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We owe an enormous debt and an enormous apology to Aboriginal people. For a government to shirk this responsibility is, in the most precise sense of the term, racist, for it reflects a view that says short‐term economic priorities in non‐indigenous society are more important than the manifest injustices inflicted on indigenous people for more than 200 years.

Mr Howard in particular seems to be in a state of denial about his discriminatory tendencies. When questioned recently about the government's removal of the right to negotiate in this bill, he gave the extraordinary response that this was not a violation of Aboriginal rights because it was a right conferred by statute and not by common law. As the National Indigenous Working Group has pointed out on many occasions, the right to negotiate has provided many Aboriginal people with their only opportunity to protect themselves from the negative impact of development on their traditional lands. Whether the right derives from statute or common law is of little importance to Aboriginal people attempting to maintain their custodial responsibility in the face of hundreds of mining companies seeking to exploit their traditional lands. Perhaps too the Prime Minister needs to be reminded that pastoral leases are also a property right conferred by statute.

When the government says that the native title holder's right to negotiate on a pastoral lease is inequitable because pastoralists do not have the same right, it dangerously echoes the sentiments of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). If this government has adopted the Hansonite view that Aboriginal people have been afforded special privileges which must now be stemmed in order to preserve some warped view of equality, it stands condemned for ignoring both the history and the current reality of Aboriginal oppression and fourth world standing in our society. As Phillip Adams recently identified, there is something far worse than racism, and that is exploitation of the racism of others for short‐term advantage. In addition, when the government presents such a view, it deliberately ignores the view that the right to negotiate was a trade‐off for widespread validation in the Native Title Act.

Over the last few months we have heard the mining industry complaining repeatedly about the unworkability of the Native Title Act. Their calls have confused the community, shaken the resolve of the Labor Party and been taken up with glee by the government. On the weekend we saw the mining industry go so far as to take out full‐page advertisements in support of the government's legislation. The government and the mining industry are hand in glove.

What the advertisements do not reveal is that, while Aboriginal people have continuously demonstrated a willingness to negotiate and reach compromise, many mining companies, in conjunction with hostile state governments, have deliberately sought to sabotage the native title process. So used to getting their way behind closed doors and being able to ride roughshod over indigenous rights, they have only come into the native title process kicking and screaming. In Western Australia the Court government has joined in, spending millions of dollars, launching ludicrously unsuccessful High Court actions rather than accepting the reality of native title.

Conservative governments have made much of the burden of future act provisions which require negotiation with multiple claimants. It is difficult to establish on what basis their complaints can be considered genuine, because the act's regime has barely been implemented according to the law of native title as established by the legislation in the courts. The thousands of potentially illegal future acts granted on pastoral leases since 1994 which this government now wishes to validate provide a graphic example of the way in which state governments have gone about flagrantly breaching the native title act.

Until two years ago, when the state of Western Australia was ordered to negotiate in good faith, as required by the act in the courts, the Court government's strategy was simply to wait until the negotiation period under the Native Title Act had elapsed and then to apply for a tribunal determination. Nevertheless, Western Australia appears to be the jurisdiction in which the future act regime is most fully utilised. Moreover it is also the jurisdiction in which it appears that native title claimants have made the most use of the act to lodge applications. It has not only the highest number of claims but also the highest number of overlapping claims in Australia. It is, therefore, in Western Australia that it might be expected that the so‐called unworkability of the system would be most apparent.

In spite of this, the mining industry, which is most involved with the future act regime of native title in Western Australia, is highly prospective. Areas subject to mining tenement applications to the Department of Minerals and Energy in 1996‐97 had increased by more than 10 million hectares since 1991‐92. With this kind of prolific development, it is difficult to sustain the position that the existing Native Title Act has resulted in an unworkable system. Would the whole of Western Australia need to be subject to mining tenements before the advocates of amendment considered there was a workable system?

It is true that overlapping claims have resulted in a level of tension and anguish within Aboriginal communities. Nonetheless, it appears somewhat patronising for non‐indigenous people to imagine that indigenous communities are incapable of dealing with these contentious issues. On numerous occasions, indigenous communities have demonstrated their ability to reach workable outcomes.

To insist that systems of communal native title will fit neatly and distinctly into a particular system of land and waters without overlapping is ethnocentric in the extreme. Perhaps if John Howard had bothered to spend any time in Aboriginal communities in the last year, he would have a greater understanding of what Justice Brennan in Mabo termed: . . . a subtle and elaborate system of rules adapted to the country in which they led their lives and providing a stable order of society remarkably free from vagaries of personal whim and influence.

This unworkability line is one of the most astonishingly hypocritical arguments in the entire native title debate. So what if a mining company has to negotiate with more than one native title claimant group? If a mining company wanted to dig up a dirty great big hole in the see of Bennelong, I reckon you would have about 50,000 people to negotiate with.

What is more, as more than one native title claimant has pointed out to me, it is not considered unworkable that native title claimants have to be involved in negotiations with multiple mining companies over possibly hundreds of different future act proposals which affect their land. It seems clear that the changes proposed are not so much directed towards meeting indigenous concerns as towards addressing the time frames of the mining corporations of Australia.

Former Liberal MP Ian Viner told the joint parliamentary committee looking at this bill that, from his experience on the Native Title Tribunal, the present act has been working well. He went on to say:
What this bill aims to do would only create more uncertainty.

It is absolutely essential to the maintenance of Aboriginal culture, identity and independence that their native title rights on pastoral leases be confirmed and maintained. Remember, what this government wishes to do is extinguish and remove those rights.

There are many examples of this need, but I will speak to just one, in my home state of Western Australia. The traditional lands of the Ngarinyin people of the Kimberley region are now covered by 12 pastoral leases. Their land claim has been running for decades. They followed the Mabo case into the High Court and were then diverted to the Native Title Tribunal. Their link to the land goes back to time immemorial; rock art in their country has been confirmed as being at least 17,000 years old.

Just this year, the Ngarinyin people were treated with the kind of indignity and subjected to the type of shame that Australians should now have put far behind us—no less than an act of apartheid. And it was all because their land now happens to be subjected to pastoral lease occupation. In July of this year, Ngarinyin lawmen led a party of dignitaries, including the Anglican Archbishop of Perth, Peter Carnley, to visit sacred and learning sites in their country. The tour is part of their tremendous Ngarinyin `bush university' initiative. Yet, incredibly, after visiting the famous Guyan Guyan paintings at the Drysdale River station, the group was prevented from leaving the station by a two‐metre high earthen wall which had been hastily bulldozed into place by the pastoralist. It took the group nearly an hour, working with a shovel and bare hands, to remove enough earth to clear a path for vehicles. When asked why the wall had been erected, the pastoralist replied that she and she alone wanted to determine who could have access to the lease.

This is not a black armband view of history; this is Western Australia in 1997. It is a graphic example of why the coexistence model established in common law by the Wik decision needs to be fully implemented without derogation or qualification. It is why the extinguishment contemplated by this government—why the removal of indigenous rights so that people such as the Ngarinyin will have to rely on the charity of pastoralists—is totally unacceptable. I would like to quote from what the Ngarinyin Kamali Council have said themselves:

We are realising that people in Canberra and Perth and Brisbane don't want us to continue our culture in our country, so are making paper laws to outlaw recognition of who we are, and our relationship in our birthright country.
You see, we didn't come from anywhere else. We don't belong anywhere else. We can't go anywhere else.

Our tribe of Ngarinyin—maybe 600 people—belong in that country where those 12 small newcomer families are trying to grow their cattle. These families keep changing because cattle don't grow enough money for them to stay there.

Now the families are growing their money from tourism. Tourists who want to learn about Ngarinyin culture visit our sacred waterholes, photograph our living images in the rocks, our Wandjina paintings.

They are taking tourists to our cultural sites where we are not allowed to go with our visitors, where we are not allowed to create employment for our young people, where we are not allowed to grow money for our communities, our people who are dying from boredom, despair and alcohol in reserves.

This is what `extinguishment' really means. It means killing off our chance to survive as a living culture, as a people, as participants in the future of Australia. It means extinguishing our birthright and meaning.
And also:

We Ngarinyin are developing up a bush university to take people into our country, to teach them the meaning of relationship in land. We are doing this because we are sorry for people who are looking for meaning in their lives and are lost to their identity. We want to share our knowledge with them. We are doing this because we want their lives to be enriched with meaning they can get from learning how to receive identity from the land. When they are grounded in the real world which is Earth, they become happy. They stop wandering around lost to themselves. This is our gift.
If our identity is extinguished, instead of receiving this gift, Australia will live with the shame of our extinguishment.

We ask the non‐government senators to heed the wishes of indigenous Australians and reject this bill. In particular we ask the Australian Labor Party and Senator Harradine to heed the wishes of the National Indigenous Working Group, the chair of the reconciliation council, the former chair of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and every Aboriginal person that I have spoken to since this bill was first released and reject the bill at the second reading.

We ask the ALP and Senator Harradine to seriously consider the implications of exposing indigenous land rights to this bill. We ask why there is a need to run the risk of this bill passing through parliament. Do the ALP or Senator Harradine really consider that anything acceptable to this government will be for the benefit of Aboriginal people or will have been achieved with the free and informed consent of the Aboriginal community? We ask the ALP whether they truly consider that there has been sufficient consultation with Aboriginal people in the formulation of this bill. Most of all, we ask the ALP not to gamble with the native title rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

If the non‐government senators are determined to deal with the sections of this bill which have broad cross‐party support then they should support the Greens' compromise proposal to split the bill so as to extract the indigenous land use agreement and so‐called Brandy provision from an otherwise highly discriminatory piece of legislation. We ask for other senators' support so that debate does not mark the beginning of the end of conciliation between the indigenous and non‐indigenous people of this country and that healing might continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I do want to make it clear at the outset of this debate tonight that I will not speak in any detail about the legislation. I will do that during the committee stage of the bill. But it is essential, in my view, that all Australians listening to this debate, whether they be in Bourke or Balmain, seek to understand the attitudes which underpin this government's response to the High Court judgment on Wik. To do so, I would ask them to cast their minds back to 6 June 1995—the night that John Howard delivered his first headland speech. He used the occasion to set out `a modern Liberal approach to the role of government'.

SPEECH.PARA: The first principle of good government, he told his audience, was to lead and unite Australians by engendering a sense of com mon purpose and community cooperation. This legislation is a telling example of how Prime Minister John Howard and his government have forsaken his first principle of good government. Mr Howard is not a leader on these issues; he is a follower. The evidence is there for all to see on the parliamentary and public record.

To my utter dismay, since the election last year we have seen, under Mr Howard's leadership, the worst division between Australians that I have witnessed in all of my adult life. Aboriginal Australia effectively lost its voice in government on the night of the last election. One need look no further than that first headland speech to find the reason why. The Prime Minister told his audience:

There is a frustrated mainstream in Australia today which sees government decisions increasingly driven by the noisy, self‐interested clamour of powerful vested interests with scant regard for the national interest.
He said, about this style of government:
would change profoundly under the Liberal and National parties. Under us—
he said—
the views of all particular interests will be assessed against the national interests and the sentiments of mainstream Australia.

The Prime Minister firmly believes that this legislation is in the national interest because it reflects the views of mainstream Australia. He knows that mainstream Australia has difficulty in associating the history of colonisation, dispossession and government control of Aboriginal people with the problems seen today in the indigenous community. He knows that the subject of equity for indigenous people in mainstream Australia is clouded by long held presumptions and myths. It is there in black and white in the extensive research which has been conducted on behalf of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet before and since the coalition assumed government. I have read it. It has been provided to this Senate through the estimates process.

From day one of this government, the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, has fed those presumptions and myths back into mainstream Australia at every possible opportunity. His rhetoric mirrors his research. He has used it to conduct a cold war of attrition against articulate indigenous leaders such as the Dodsons, the O'Donoghues and others. In the process, this Prime Minister has all but destroyed the process of reconciliation.

Criticism has been rightly directed at participants on both sides of this debate for emotional and inaccurate generalisations about the Wik decision and this legislation. A great deal of this, however, was generated from the top by the inexcusable performance of our Prime Minister on national television holding up a map of Australia and making the unqualified and completely false statement that the Wik decision would allow Aborigines `to stop development over 78 per cent of Australia'. It, of course, allowed nothing of the sort.

The Prime Minister has also joined his Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) and others in criticising the so‐called judicial activism of the High Court. I wondered at the time about how they would react if their rights before the courts were dismissed in the same cavalier fashion as they wish to dismiss those of indigenous Australians. All the High Court was doing, as anyone who has bothered to read the judgments would know—whether you agree or disagree with them—was its job of determining an issue for litigants on the facts placed before it. God help us if the court ever stops doing that! I can find, in fact, no better defence of the rightful role of the High Court than the concluding passage from the judgment of Mr Justice McHugh in the Waanyi case. His Honour said:

The community will quickly lose confidence in the courts of justice if a perception arises that the courts are ready to ignore the legal rights of individuals whenever intervening governments or litigants urge that public or private convenience requires such rights to be by‐passed.

Hear! Hear! But this is precisely what the Prime Minister hopes to achieve with this legislation. He wants to see the common law rights of indigenous people bypassed. This government will brook no opposition, but what a mess it has created in the process!

In just two days last week, we had the Prime Minister deliver a set piece assault on the nation's church leaders from the floor of this parliament while, at the same time, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, was telling the Governor‐General, Sir William Deane to back off—his words—in speaking out on Aboriginal issues. In his prime ministerial admonition, Mr Howard advised church leaders that the right to speak freely carried with it the obligation to do so `in an informed, objective and constructive manner'. Our Prime Minister, unfortunately, does not practise what he preaches.

I have already spoken of the prime ministerial television appearance which could not have been more ill‐informed and destructive. Honourable senators may also recall that the Prime Minister called his first press conference in Canberra as Prime Minister to announce that he was putting a special auditor into ATSIC and freezing the flow of funds to hundreds of indigenous organisations around this country. He also announced that the government would seek legislative change, which they did, to give them the power to sack the entire ATSIC board and install an administrator. This was the first press conference in Canberra of the newly elected Prime Minister. The appointment of the special auditor was later found by the Federal Court to be unlawful and this Senate blocked the attempt to impose an administrator on ATSIC if the government so desired.

The point is that all of this was done by the Howard government without a single word of prior consultation with a single Aboriginal person or with ATSIC, the principal policy adviser in indigenous affairs to this government. Had he or his minister bothered to consult ATSIC, they would have been informed, as the Senate now knows, that a major review was already under way into the very issue and was due to report shortly. The special auditor, in fact, cleared 95 per cent of those Aboriginal corporations and the review—the one the Prime Minister never bothered to acquaint himself with—has subsequently reported that those corporations are 60 times more accountable than similar non‐indigenous organisations incorporated under state laws. This report has been sitting on the minister's desk for more than one year now with no action.

That one news conference and the subsequent alarmist nationwide media coverage reinforced decades of misinformation and myth about accountability in Aboriginal affairs and it came, I regret to say, from the top. The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, to his shame, even defended the government's action at that news conference by citing here in the Senate tabloid press reports which incorrectly claimed that the special auditor had found 95 per cent of the organisations in contravention of their grant conditions. When we pointed this out, and it is a matter of public record, to the minister he agreed that the newspaper reports were absolute garbage, but he said—and it is in the Hansard—that it was not his duty to inform the Senate as to the accuracy of the newspaper reports from which he was quoting. So much for the prime ministerial duty to speak in an informed, objective and constructive manner.

Can you imagine a national government dealing with any other part of its constituency in such a dismissive and deceitful way? This was not an isolated incident. The Prime Minister and his government have continued in the way they started. I cite, for example, the shameful fiasco over Pat Dodson's reappointment to the National Council for Reconciliation. I think I speak on behalf of most Australians when I say that, over those five or six years, Mr Dodson has established for himself a reputation as one of the most distinguished Australians in public life today, and it is a loss to the nation that he is not there.

As Pat Dodson told the Australian last week—I thought he put the point well—he had given five or six years of his life to progressing national reconciliation through the council and the government could not wait five or six days to talk to him about whether he should be reappointed or not. One could spend hours reciting the offence that this lack of consultation has caused indigenous Australia. Suffice it to say that, in pursuing his indigenous affairs agenda, this Prime Minister has sought no meaningful counsel in Aboriginal Australia.

The Prime Minister clearly has no understanding of how important consultation is to Aboriginal people. He appears to genuinely fear the exercise of indigenous economic and political power, and he publicly equates self-determination with separatism. He was saying the same thing in the parliamentary debates on the establishment of ATSIC a decade ago. The debate has moved on. The Prime Minister has not.

I have a number of constituents sitting in the public gallery tonight who are so concerned about this legislation that they have travelled thousands of kilometres from the Territory to express their concerns. They feel that this legislation does not provide them with justice. I would like to read out a statement that they have provided to me on behalf of their communities. The statement to the Prime Minister and federal parliament reads:
We are the women landowners and land council members from across Northern Australia and we call on the Prime Minister and the Federal Parliament to respect and defend our native title rights.

We are lifting our voices for our rights, for our dreaming and for our culture, and for the future of our children, grandchildren and great‐grandchildren. We are speaking from our hearts for our culture, our spirituality and our law.

We want all Australians to understand that their children's rights in the land and the sea will also be diminished by the so-called 10 point plan. How will Australians be able to protect the environment for all the children if the Parliament hands over the rights of all Australians to a few big companies?
Under your amendments, Mr Howard, development can go ahead without even talking to us, damaging our culture and our law, damaging our traditional hunting grounds, and polluting our environment.

Our law tells us that our rights to land and sea cannot be broken. We are responsible for our sacred places and our traditional country from the beginning of time to the end of time. We are responsible for ensuring that the law is passed on and that our land is protected. Our spirituality can be seen and heard in our songs and dances. Native title is the recognition by Australian law of our customary spirituality and our responsibilities for land.

We reject the proposed amendments to the Native Title Act. They are an attack on our life, our religious beliefs and on our spiritual relationships with the land and sea. Sea country is just as much a part of our law as the dry land. Our people's dreamings include the dolphin, the crocodile, the turtle, the stingray and the dugong, as well as birds and all the other native animals.

We do not accept the denial of our rights on pastoral leases and other land. We will not give up our right to negotiate because the right to have a say over our country is our life. The right to negotiate enables us to protect our culture and our future.
We instruct our land councils to do everything possible to protect our rights to land and sea.
We take responsibility on behalf of all Australians and future generations to call for an end to the hysteria which is dividing this country.
We ask the women of Australia of all cultures to support us.
We will not give up our fight for our inherited rights.
Hear, hear!

I attended a meeting in this building this afternoon with that women's delegation. The chairman of the meeting asked Mary Yamirr, who is a senior landowner—indeed, a leader of the Aboriginal community at Minjilang, Croker Island, whom I have known for 30 years—`What is it we can do to help heal these wounds, to help reduce the tension and division currently in the community?' I wrote down what she said. These are the words of the leader of a small Aboriginal community in Minjilang, in the Northern Territory. She said:
We believe that all of us should live together in this country respecting each other's law and culture.
What a shame we do not have a national leader who holds the same views.

In my view, there are three ways a national government can respond to the Wik judgment. It can legislate, litigate or negotiate. There are many people throughout Australia, both indigenous and non-indigenous, pastoralists and non-pastoralists, who understand that this government will not provide them with certainty in this legislation. If this legislation passes through this parliament unamended, it will simply lead to more litigation.

What will help to deliver certainty is negotiation. The government should be big enough to acknowledge that the controversial elements of this legislation must be amended. We are prepared, as the government knows, to support valid amendments to this legislation. As I said on ABC radio in Darwin this morning, a number of these amendments were already in train when we were in government as a result of the Brandy and Waanyi decisions. But we will not adopt the same dog in the manger approach that this government did when in opposition.

When John Howard last lost the leadership of the Liberal Party in the late eighties, he described the prospect of his returning to the leadership as—I quote him—Lazarus with a triple bypass. Now that he has succeeded to the highest political office in the land, a question now remains: has John Howard been left with enough heart for the job?

It will take a lot of heart to admit it, but let us admit that the fears and apprehensions about native title are in the mind, not on the land. This bill, as it has been presented to this parliament, is discriminatory, unfair and legally flawed. Indigenous people say so; members of this government say so; the Prime Minister's legal advice says so; external legal advice says so; the churches say so; a host of community groups say so; and the High Court ultimately will say so. It is surely time for this government to say so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lightfoot, Sen Phillip

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the chamber for the opportunity to speak tonight on what I think—certainly in my time in politics since 1986—is the most important piece of legislation that I have ever had the opportunity of addressing. I speak in very generic terms tonight in the second reading debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 in support of the government amendments. I particularly direct my contribution to Western Australia, a state to which I owe much and which I know very well.

SPEECH.PARA: Western Australia contributes an enormous amount to the federal economy. It comprises 9.7 per cent of the nation and has some 1.78 million people, yet it contributes 30 per cent of export income. It contributes that income as a result of the ingenuity of the people who choose to reside in Western Australia and those God‐given rights and elements that we have been so blessed with.

If we were to agree with what Senator Bob Collins and other speakers on his side of the House have just outlined—that we should allow the right to negotiate to continue—Western Australia would fail in its contribution to the nation, so the nation would suffer. If we were to reach some sort of consensus with Aboriginal and Euro-Aboriginal people, we would also, by mere dint of the legislation that exists at the moment, if it were not amended, also fall behind.

I believe—I speak personally here—that Australia is my country and Australia is the country of those constituents in Western Australia whom I represent here. Australia belongs to all people. Australia is not a nation that should be divided because of the colour of one's skin. Australia is not a nation that should take any pride in singling out people for racial discrimination. But Australia has a duty to people of this nation, not just people of one particular colour and not just because of a person's background or particular religion. It is not a sectarian issue; this is an issue that is based on race. This is an issue that the government is trying to redress so that it equates to a distribution of wealth for all people.

Western Australia is a nation blessed with mineral resources. We have the biggest diamond mine in the world, producing some 38 million carats of diamonds annually. We have the biggest iron ore mines in the world, producing billions of dollars worth of iron ore exports annually and competing with the Carajas mine in Brazil as the equal biggest. Western Australia is the fourth biggest producer of gold in the world. Western Australia is the biggest exporter of alumina powder in the world. Western Australia is the fifth biggest producer of nickel in the world, in all sorts of shapes and formulae. This year Western Australia will produce over 10 million tonnes of wheat.

Western Australia is rich by any means. But when the dead hand of native title claims 82 per cent of Western Australia, as it is at the moment, Western Australia will cease to be a world leader and a major contributor to the federal economy. Then there will be people—perhaps there are some here tonight, living off the public purse—who may regret their actions. Maybe there will be people who will regret their actions tonight; ill-informed people who do not understand that, in order to maintain a democracy like we enjoy—one of the oldest in the world—we need to have an economy that is commensurate with that.
