Where you do not have social services to the degree that we do in Australia rightly looking after people, then you have poor economies. They go together.

I want to make sure during my time here that I do what I believe is best for all Australians. I am not going to single out any particular group, nor am I going to deny the rights that Aboriginal people have in this nation—rights given to them in equality and in fairness and in lateness, in 1967, when they were ushered into the Australian family with all its benefits. That measure was some decades, if not some generations, late in coming.

If 82 per cent of Western Australia at the moment were not subject to native title claims, Aboriginal people—or those who choose to be called Aboriginal people—would still have 50 sheep and cattle stations in Western Australia. They would still have their historic Aboriginal lands. Those amount to 38 million acres. To put that in perspective, that is greater than the aggregate of the United Kingdom. It is a vast area of land if one single native title claim does not succeed! I think it is rather interesting to note that the only single native title claim that has succeeded by negotiations to date since 1993 is an area of freehold land in New South Wales that was sold within minutes of its being granted.

One has to ask oneself about the bona fides attached to some Aboriginal people. I do not include all Aboriginal people in that. I have spent a great deal of my life, if not all of it, juxtaposed with Aboriginal people and I must say that I have the greatest deal of respect for them, but they are not the people who are driving the Aboriginal industry. A lot of these people here tonight hissing and trying to intimidate speakers like me are the ones who are driving the Aboriginal industry, and that is a big problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is called democracy. They are actually entitled to a say, Ross.

—I am not going to be drawn into the simplistic retort by Senator Forshaw, but let me say this in case it is said of me that I concentrated on the economics of the problems that exist and that face Australia today: it is not the economics solely that worry me. That is certainly a preoccupation of mine—and I do not deny it—but what worries me also is the division that is being driven between Aboriginal people, Euro‐Aboriginal people and other Australians. I find that dangerous. I find that dangerous in the extreme.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want divisions in Australia like those that exist in the United States of America, like that that existed in what was then Rhodesia, like that that existed in the old South Africa and still exist there. I do not want that. I do not want that sort of discrimination and division that exists today in India, where the untouchable caste system still exists. I want people of all colour and all ilks and all backgrounds to be equal in this nation, one of the greatest democracies on earth.

This nation is equal in its area to the United States of America—three million square miles each—and yet in it we have 19 million people and in the United States of America there are 250 million‐odd people. There is plenty of land for everyone, but it must not be an issue where hatred and division are promoted on the basis of the colour of someone's skin and, in turn, on land. That should not happen.

Let me read a few things to do with the mining industry and those problems facing Western Australia, because Western Australia's problems become Australia's problems in economic terms. I know that we are a long way away. I know that we suffer the tyranny of distance. I know we are seen by others sometimes as something of an oddity, but we are actually good Australians. We contribute more than our share to the privy purse and we do not worry about that because we know there are other areas in Australia, particularly social areas, that need that wealth that Western Australia generates.

BREAK.PARA: But all I ask is that you let us continue to generate that area that we have some expertise in and that flows back to Australia, because it is of great benefit to the whole nation. When we earn 30 per cent of export income with less than 10 per cent of the people, of course Western Australia contributes to the nation. When we are 9.7 per cent of the population and yet we pay 10.6 per cent of income tax to the nation, we pay more than our share. But we cannot continue to do it unless we resolve Aboriginal ambit claims.

Let me quote a case: a company wishing to extend their existing pit operations in and around Kalgoorlie were forced to pay $500,000 in cash to one Aboriginal family to continue their operations; otherwise the mine would have shut down. That family happened to live in Albany—not meeting the threshold test as proposed under the 10‐point plan but that was what we were subject to because of the right to negotiate. Half a million dollars went out there.

Let me quote another one: a company wishing to establish a new $21 million processing plant and to develop a new ore body have suspended their expansion plans due to the demands placed on them by native title claimants. That is not good for the native title claimants even if they are bona fide. That has to be rectified. The 10-point plan will rectify that problem.

No. 3: a mining group, having put their treatment plant under `care and maintenance' because of their inability to convert prospecting licences to mining licences because of native title claimants, have walked away. That is not good for the national economy.
No. 4: a sandmining contractor who has been operating in the region around Kalgoorlie for years, providing garden sand, has closed his entire business because it is subject to native title claim.

No. 5: most mining operators have received letters from representatives of several different claimant groups—almost invariably from a lawyer—offering to inspect the claimed tenement area for a fee, with the clear indication that a failure to provide work to that group may result in difficult and protracted negotiations further down the track. These `letters of demand' proposed payments for the `Aboriginal attendants' of $500 and upwards per person per day and the provision of a good quality four‐wheel drive vehicle for the entire period of the investigation, generally unspecified but left open ended.

Again, around Kalgoorlie and juxtaposed to those areas around Kalgoorlie, a small mining tenement attracted `fees' of $1,200 per claimant per day for the claimants to inspect the site for clearance. The total aggregate of the cost of the clearance was $85,000.

No. 7: many large mining concerns are increasingly diverting their exploration budget overseas. For the first time in our history, more of Australians' exploration dollars are going overseas, and it is because of the dead hand of native title claim. If we can fix that, if we can make sure that the threshold tests meet what we would consider to be reasonable, those dollars will flow back into Australia for exploration. No exploration, no mines. No mines, then Western Australia ceases to become the premier exporting state of this nation and all Australians, including Aboriginal and Euro‐Aboriginal Australians, will suffer.

Many large mining concerns of course know that they cannot meet the demands made by some unscrupulous claimants. I am careful in not saying all are, and I want that to be a matter of record. Some claimants—many of them, indeed—are bona fide claimants, and they have my sympathy.

A large mining concern has been told to hand over its substantial pastoral holdings, or Aboriginal groups will no longer negotiate clearances for its mining operations. I have already told you that Aboriginal people own 50 sheep and cattle stations in Western Australia. The Mungari industrial park was set up four or five years ago between Coolgardie and Kalgoorlie. The park, subject to the native title claim system, carried out the mining concern's clearance obligations. Local Aboriginal representatives identified two small sites of significance. The planning then protected those sites by appropriate buffers against any surrounding development, limiting the area of the park.

After the development was completed, another group of different Aboriginal people claimed other significant sites, and these too were subsequently deleted from the park boundary. During a further clearance process for the industrial waste site, an anthropologist identified a site which is now protected under the relevant act. That site measures only 0.5 metres by one metre and consists of a broken bottle described in the report as `a scatter of green bottle glass with a total of 16 pieces'.

May I now shift on to sandalwood operators—not people associated with St Georges Terrace entrepreneurs, not people associated with multimillionaires, but hardworking people who use their ingenuity and their bushcraft to survive. Sandalwood operators, harvesting on crown land, now have to obtain native title clearance prior to commencing operation. This obviously, to people who know the industry and who know the area, is going to take years and will destroy the sandalwood industry. The industry is dealing with overseas purchasers who obviously demand action. Pastoralists who have operated on stock accounts with pastoral houses and overdrafts at banks have had severe limits placed upon them due to the insecurity of their tenure. Their ability to maintain viable operations with limited financial accommodation is restricted.

Towns like Kalgoorlie, Coolgardie, Leonora, Laverton, Yalgoo, Meekatharra, Mount Magnet and Cue have all been curtailed in their expansion because of native title being claimed right up to their boundaries. For instance, in Kalgoorlie a house purchased for $56,000 in 1995 recently sold for $162,000, because of the restricted supply of land. A quarter acre lot purchased for $80,000 eight months ago has attracted an offer of $120,000.

I wonder whether all of this is worth the dissension, the division, the hatred and the antipathy that is going on. I do not want to see my country divided, but what I can tell this house tonight is that this is my country. This country belongs to 19 million people. This country does not belong to any section or community. This country does not belong to two per cent of the population. This coun try belongs to those people who live and reside here and who choose to be called Australians. I do not want to see my country further divided. I do not want to see the continuing hatred, although I fear it is going to burgeon. I do not want to see these problems artificially promoted that are likely to divide us.

I do believe that this is the greatest country in the world. It will only continue to be so if we are able to cope with this problem before us—if we are able to debate it and if everyone has the opportunity to so do and not be curtailed in what they have to say. Neither one side nor the other can lay claim to being more passionate about being an Australian—not your sectional interests, Labor, not yours, Democrats, not yours, Greens, and certainly not mine.

I am going to finish by saying this: I do believe that we can resolve the problem. I do not believe that division is necessarily the best way to go. I do not believe that an adversarial approach to it is the best way. I am sure we can resolve it. We need the 10-point plan to be implemented to resolve it. I have watched it, I have studied it and I have read it carefully. It will resolve the problem. It will not detract from Aboriginal claimants, nor would I support it if it did. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —In the next two weeks this parliament will be given a unique, historic opportunity to meet the moral, cultural and economic challenges surrounding the native title entitlements with which we are faced. These challenges we cannot ignore; we might wish to, but we cannot. We are faced with a number of High Court decisions which we must consider, the latest of which is the decision known colloquially as the Wik decision. All that that decision in fact did was to hold that the granting of a pastoral lease, whether or not the lease had now expired, did not necessarily extinguish all native title rights and interests that might otherwise exist. It sounds somewhat innocuous. But that decision raised more questions than it solved, and it is those questions that we must address when we are giving consideration in the committee stage to the clauses of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 .

SPEECH.PARA: Why are we faced with these challenges which emerge from the courts? The reason is that legislatures, both state and federal, over a number of years, have refused or failed to deal with the important issue of native title. The 1993 Native Title Act was a response by the then government to Mabo. The Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 is this government's response to Wik.

The question is: how do we in this parliament respond? We can either do so negatively or positively. We can see this as an opportunity—an opportunity to contribute to reconciliation and restoration of trust; an opportunity to address these issues, applying the principles of social justice, of fairness, of distributive justice; an opportunity to deal with the issues without affecting, but in fact promoting, the development of Australia.

How are we going to do that? It would be desirable for all of us to do so with a degree of decorum and dignity, if we can bring it out, and also with as much nous as we possibly can. There should be an informed debate. When we walk into this place, we should leave the guns of ambit claims at the door. We should not approach the issue with an `ambit attitude'.

It might be said by the drafters of the 10‐point plan that there were consultations; indeed, there were—a large number of consultations in the development of the 10‐point plan. By and large, that plan has been incorporated in the legislation that is before us.

However, I feel that nobody would be surprised to be told that the legislation, as printed, requires substantial amendment before it passes this chamber. I believe the Prime Minister has indicated as much, inferentially at least, by the fact that he gave a commitment prior to the last election that the Racial Discrimination Act would not be impaired.

Of course, as a result of that, one needs to look carefully at this legislation to assess whether it contains any discriminatory provisions and any decisions which would arbitrarily extinguish native title. We also have to have regard, I suppose, to what might occur in the Hindmarsh Bridge case, and the interpretation that may be given in that judgment to the constitutional provisions and how they should operate.

I believe, and I hope, that there will be an absence of political points scoring during the debate. There has been a little bit of that up to date in the second reading stage—a little disappointing. But I do not think this measure, as important as it is, should be used as a political football or for the grandstanding of members to the media or anybody else.

The media at times inflames more than it informs; but on this particular subject, by and large, those times have been the exception. However, I do appeal to the media to let us get on with it and give us a bit of space, a bit of a breather, so that we can, over the next week, be able to engage in those discussions, without everybody breathing down our necks as to what we are doing, whom we have talked to and what arrangements we have come to, and so on. I do make that appeal.

We do want to get on with it. We should be open to honourable compromise. It will be a difficult time. Of course, not all of the measures in this piece of legislation are contentious. Quite a considerable amount of this legislation is not contentious—for example, those provisions that are to amend the Native Title Act 1993, having regard to the Brandy decision.

Certainly, at the end of the day, we want to have a bill which, as far as is possible, gives certainty—certainty about the rights and interests of the various stakeholders; certainty about the procedures to be adopted. Hopefully, those procedures—those streamlined procedures—are to be such that it will not cost an arm and a leg either to pursue applications for native title, or to contest them.

I do hope that at the end of the day we come up with some piece of legislation—we have got to have something—which, whilst it will not satisfy all the stakeholders, nevertheless will be a piece of legislation that they can live with. Obviously, whenever it might be, at the end of the day the government will need to consent to the legislation, since whatever happens here will have to go to the House of Representatives. I do hope that, if we take that approach, the government is more likely to hear and ultimately to agree. I certainly do not want to see a divisive election, and the prospect of a double dissolution election about this particular matter is something that is concerning me. It is, I believe, a weight on people's minds right around Australia.

On this matter I have received thousands and thousands of letters and representations. Let me say to those who have written to me that I do appreciate what you have done and I am most grateful for your sending those letters and making those representations. It certainly improved my knowledge of the situation. I am grateful to my staff and grateful for the persons who are praying about this issue, praying that parliament will make the right decision. I have also been assisted by the stakeholders. I have been assisted by the Parliamentary Library and the parliamentary officers of this chamber and the other chamber. As an Independent, I rely considerably on the work of the committees, and in this particular regard I pay tribute to the work of the native title committee, and particularly the staff of that committee. There have been 30 volumes of submissions, and I very much appreciate their help. Before I go on, I must say that I hope you recognise that it is impossible for me to write to all of those people who have written to me. I feel embarrassed about that, but I hope you understand that it is impossible for me to write in response to all of the letters.

I believe also that the various task forces, including the Wik task force, have been quite helpful. I do not accept really that they approach their task with a racist approach. I do not accept that. That type of statement does not help the situation, nor does the statement of attack on the churches. I know that some of these statements are born of frustration and false fear. I will not go into that, because time does not permit me to, but there were certain beliefs as a result of the 1993 Native Title Act which have been found to have been unwarranted. One could make a number of quotes.

I voted for the Native Title Act. I just refer you to the Hansard for what I said on that particular occasion. But I also said that it was flawed and we would have to revisit it. Well, we have had to revisit it, and we are doing that right here and now. Mabo, of course, decided that terra nullius was a legal fiction. There have been Aboriginal tribes here for thousands of years. There has been a tradition established, and we need a respect for that tradition and the relationship which Aboriginals have with the land. For thousands of years they have savoured the soil and the land. Some would say, `Forget tradition. We are in a modern society. We are a democracy, we are in control. In today's quick fix economic rationalist democracy there is no place for tradition.'

To those who say that there is little or no place for tradition, I would like to say that a modern nation which ignores tradition is unworthy to be called a true democracy. Why? Because tradition is the democracy of the dead. Through tradition, our ancestors have their say; through tradition, our forebears speak to us. We must be sensitive to these non‐material truths. Many Aboriginals are in fact concerned about some of their own who adopt a purely materialistic view. There is good and bad in everyone. There are ratbags around the place, and I know there are some concerns being expressed on some of the claims by the Aboriginal people themselves. Some suggest that some of those who are involved in it are attempting to make a fast buck. There are certain measures in this legislation which might in fact address that matter.

The skills of Aboriginals have been very important over the years. My father, who was a great hunter out bush where I was born and raised, used to tell me and show me how the Aboriginals tracked their prey. Of course, tradition is not confined to the Aboriginal stakeholders. Other stakeholders, whether miners or pastoral leaseholders, do themselves have great traditions. Many of them were distressed, and feel distressed now, by the actions of some of their forebears. But let us not judge too much in those particular areas. There were certain abhorrent actions taken and those actions need to be condemned—but the question is whether they should be visited upon future generations.

BREAK.PARA: The pioneers—my grandfather was the boiler attendant at the Finke—went through great hardships. Women pioneers in particular went through great hardships. I do not need to tell this chamber how hospitable the people of the bush are.

Parliament is challenged. We cannot walk away from that challenge. It is our responsibility. It surely is not the court's responsibility to legislate. We are the legislators; they are the judges. But there are certain matters of principle that we must uphold. Terra nullius was described as a `legal fiction'. And so it was. When the first fleeters came there were people in this land. When those first fleeters came this country was already declared, and is still, Terra Australis—the great southern land. We all have a passion for Terra Australis. We are all stakeholders in Terra Australis and we in this Senate do have a responsibility to address this matter against the principles that I have suggested. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 December 1862 Abraham Lincoln in his annual message to Congress said:

SPEECH.PARA: Fellow‐citizens, we cannot escape history. We of this Congress and this Administration will be remembered in spite of ourselves. No personal significance, or insignificance, can spare one or another of us. The fiery trial through which we pass will light us down, in honour or dishonour, to the latest generation.

He was talking during a momentous civil war whose genesis was a conflict within the nation over how a particular race ought be treated. The war followed a split decision made in March 1857 by the Supreme Court of the United States of America in Dred Scott v. Sandford which held that black inhabitants of that country could not become citizens and that Congress had no power to abolish their slavery.

The Senate is now engaged in a historic debate involving race relations. This follows a split decision of the High Court of Australia made on 23 December 1996 in The Wik Peoples v. The State of Queensland and Others. We cannot escape history. This is so in two senses. First, we are engaged in seeking a solution to a great issue which has been several generations in the making. We have inherited a national circumstance which has evolved over two centuries and we must deal with it fairly and effectively in less than a fortnight. Secondly, generations following ours will measure our worth as parliamentarians by the way we so deal with it.

We face a great moral issue in this debate. We face an economic and commercial issue but it is predominantly a moral one. Senators before me have spoken about the effect that the native title regime may have on the commercial and economic fate of this country. They are matters to be taken into account. But predominantly the issue is a moral one. The Australian clergy have understood that and have responded accordingly. Along with all other Australians, they have a right and a duty to see to it that the great matter before us is properly resolved. Indeed, their sense of the spiritual gives them a special responsibility. The Bible has Isaiah saying:
Woe to those who enact unjust statutes and who write oppressive decrees.
If the clergy thought that this parliament was about to do that then clearly they ought speak out.

I have said that past generations have in large measure left us the issues to which the Wik decision has drawn attention. We should acknowledge this and seek to resolve them with as much consensus as possible. That means the language of debate should be appropriate and that the various parties directly affected by its outcome should be properly recognised as having real interests to sustain.

It is essential in this debate that there be accuracy in the community's perception of the relevant facts and law; that the concepts upon which the discussion proceeds be true ones. For example, there is a perception abroad that it is unusual for a multiplicity of people to have various and discrete interests in a single piece of property. So much of the debate has turned upon who owns the land, who should own the land and what effect native title has on the land. And that debate has been carried out in the context that it is unusual in English law, which we have inherited, for there to be a multiplicity of title. But that is just not right.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to go into that a little and in doing so—I noticed Senator Harradine acknowledged his family—I would like to acknowledge my wife, who I think is one of the outstanding land lawyers in Victoria, in my discussion of land law.

TALK.START.PARA: —She will have a cup of tea waiting for him when he gets home.

—And a good one, too; but I will make it. For pastoralists and Aborigines to have coexisting interests in a particular area of land is in keeping with the concepts that have underpinned our legal system. We have heard a discussion of the pastoralists, and they are certainly entitled to the full extent of the property rights that the lease gives them. But there is a perception—which may come from the country—that city folk do not have other interests than their own in land or the house which they live in. That is not right. We have easements of way, of light—even in Darwin you have those things, Senator Collins—of sewerage and of drainage in favour of a neighbour or government. A person may own a house which is both mortgaged and tenanted and is subject to the rights of his mortgagor and of his tenant. A tenant has rights of entry and occupation, and so do the various people who bring services to the house, such as the people who bring gas, electricity and water to the house.

BREAK.PARA: Many have said that in recognising native title the High Court has allowed too much uncertainty to enter Australian law. May I say that, if you can bring certainty to the law and certainty to the situation, that is a good thing. Hopefully, at the end of the debate we will have brought more certainty than presently exists to the land law which provides a context for native title.
Land law, by its very nature, is uncertain, and Justice Brennan pointed that out in Mabo v. Queensland (No. 2) where he said:

The land law of England is based on the doctrine of tenure. In English legal theory, every parcel of land in England is held either mediately or immediately of the King, who is Lord Paramount; the term `tenure' is used to signify the relationship between tenant and lord not the relationship between tenant and land.

I will quote a passage—I know you should not quote passages in giving speeches—which I think brings it out well. It is from a textbook that we were given when we were taught law. I do not know whether Senator Forshaw had this put upon him, but I thought it was not a bad quote. It says:

Most students find the land law difficult. This is due probably to two causes: first, the method of reasoning with its almost casuistical refinements is sometimes difficult to follow; secondly, and probably more importantly, the land law is not very much concerned with land, but with interests in land that have only a notional existence. No man—
This was written a while back, and now I would hope it would say `no man or woman'—

ever saw a fee simple, which is the greatest interest in land which any citizen can hold and is usually described as ownership of the land. In fact, what is owned is the legal estate in fee simple. Again, the same piece of land may be subject to a number of different interests owned by different persons. Thus, Blackacre may be owned in fee simple by Jones, but his interest may be subject to a lease of Blackacre to Smith for ninety‐nine years who may in turn have underlet the premises to Robinson for twenty‐one years. Here are three who will talk of Blackacre of "his." In fact each is an owner, but each owns an interest and does not own the land.

It is quite clear—Senator Forshaw acknowledges this as he remembers it from his university days—that there can be a multiplicity of interests in land. To go ahead in the debate on the basis that you have pastoralists' rights and indigenous people's rights, as if those rights were contradictory and could not exist together, is just wrong and against the very concept of the law which we inherited, and that is the common law of England, from which our own law has developed.

I think there has been a lot of debate based on a concept that is just wrong—that somehow native title introduces a new concept into the scheme of things which was not there before. As my wife pointed out to me, if you look at the various acts that operate, say, in Victoria—the Heritage Act, the Town and Country Planning Act and various regulations put forward by the councils in that state—and which are repeated in other states, it becomes quite apparent that it is a wrong journey for us to go upon when we start talking about the conflict in the giving of native title and pastoral leases.

I will just make this point before closing: a number of outstanding lawyers have given opinions about various matters to do with this bill, and clearly the Senate must work within the legal parameters set by the constitution and accordingly give great weight to their advice. But we as legislators cannot shift any part of our own responsibility onto others. We must, in the discharge of our personal duties to all the nation, enact measures which are fair and effective in dealing with the legitimate claim every person has in respect of land over which native title does or may exist. In looking at that land, we must ask, `Who has interests in this?' and accord their proper entitlements to them—not simply to the indigenous people but to all those people who may have a right in that land. Parliament is the one body elected by all adult Australians and accordingly it must fulfil its functions in a proper way.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the adjournment debate tonight to comment on two unrelated but equally bizarre appearances in the national media this morning. I woke up today to see and hear Territory euthanasia campaigner, Dr Philip Nitschke, announcing to the world that he and a number of unnamed researchers were close to developing a do‐it‐yourself suicide pill.

SPEECH.PARA: According to Dr Death, his amazing laptop killing machine is about to be superseded. Dr Phil's new kill pill will be concocted from readily available household substances. He is not quite sure if he will dispense this in a form that can be readily popped into your kitchen Mixmaster or whether it will already come in pill form. He is also not sure how you get around the problem of ensuring it does not get into the wrong hands, but that has not prevented him from appearing on national television and radio to tell the world that it will be shortly available.

One assumes that the pill will be the ultimate upper or downer, depending on how you have lived your life. The timing of the good doctor—or Nitschke of the Never‐Never as he is known in some quarters—is ill‐timed to say the least. He does not seem to understand that suicide, legally assisted or not, is not the province solely of the terminally ill. No-one could be unmoved by the plight of the lingering, painful death of those with a whole range of terminal illnesses, but the point does need to be reinforced, if only in Dr Nitschke's mind.

Australia, unfortunately, has one of the highest youth suicide rates in the world. To the utter devastation of both myself and my wife, last year a 12‐year‐old boy whom we knew well committed suicide after attending what appeared to be a perfectly normal day at school. Many young people are still trying to come to terms with the tragic suicide last weekend of Michael Hutchence, the lead singer of INXS. To many young people, Michael Hutchence had it all—glamour, money and prestige. Many are legitimately confounded by the circumstances of his death and I am sure all of our hearts go out to his partner and their children. I would have thought that the last thing the public debate needed at this point in time was a media blitz by Dr Death and his suicide pill.

But possibly more bizarre—and also dealing with death—was the front page of today's Australian and the story detailing the decision of the Member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) to videotape her last will and testament in case of political assassination. I picked up the Australian to read the headline, ``Fellow Australians, if you are seeing me now, it means I have been murdered'—Pauline Hanson's video from the grave.' Madam Deputy President, I would like to inform you and reassure you and fellow Australians that, if you are seeing me now, it means I am alive and well and in the Senate and I have not been assassinated by anybody.

BREAK.PARA: It is truly bizarre. Sixty seconds of the 12‐minute video was actually broadcast tonight on national television. The Member for Oxley must now be the only member of any parliament in the world with one soundbite in the grave. What next? Coffin-cam? I believe that this extraordinary video and its public airing on the Witness program tonight will indeed remove the last shreds of public credibility from Pauline Hanson and One Nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very irresponsible!

—Indeed, it is, Senator. It is clearly a last, desperate attempt by Hanson and her acolytes to arrest the substantial erosion of the nine per cent support she enjoyed at the peak of Hanson media mania. The facts are that no‐one needs to destroy Pauline Hanson; she has done a great job on herself.

BREAK.PARA: It is very easy, in fact, to lampoon her and her fears of assassination. I enjoyed very much Mikey Robbins's reference to her on Good News Week when he said that she had the face that launched a thousand chips. I don't know why I am a big fan of Mikey Robbins—people will have to draw their own conclusions about that. I also agree with Victorian Premier Jeff Kennett's statement today that, if he had recorded a last message to the media every time he had received a death threat in his five years as Premier, he would not have had time to do any other work. Strangely enough, I have no trouble believing that either.

But there is a serious question about Ms Hanson and her security which remains unanswered. It is this: how much are the extraordinary security measures which surround every move by this backbencher costing Australian taxpayers? My Labor colleague, Janice Crosio, attempted to find out in a series of questions on notice to the government last year and all she received was a refusal to divulge any information on the spurious grounds that the government did not divulge any matters relating to the operational procedures—quite rightly—of the federal or state police. But what a nonsense; she was not asking for any details of operational procedures. She simply wanted to know, as we are all entitled to know, the cost of the extraordi nary security which surrounds every movement of this bizarre backbencher.

I have since placed my own series of questions on notice making that very point. The opposition does not want to know anything about the procedures; it simply wants to know how much it is costing taxpayers to provide such security to a backbencher. Needless to say, I await the government's response, and goodnight to you all.
